From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [cmcculloch@rmsc.com](mailto:cmcculloch@rmsc.com)
Cc: [cwelch@rmsc.com](mailto:cwelch@rmsc.com), [jessa@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:jessa@whaleylawfirm.com) Jessa Galosmo, [justin@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:justin@whaleylawfirm.com) Justin Chumbley, [BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Mon, 22 May 2023 14:59:14 -0400

Clark, I am in receipt of your denial on this claim. You assert the basis
is because my "client was confused on what transpired." Clark, she was not
confused as to what happened. She was confused as to where your driver came
from since he turned in front of her. If someone turned right in front of
me I might be confused as to where they came from as well. Does your
vehicle have a camera? That would possibly resolve the dispute. Let me
know. Thanks.

-- 
Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Ln
Louisville, KY 40222
502-583-4022
episodes.natural_language:
This case note concerns Brenda Lang’s motor vehicle accident case, Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, file number 410220052. On Monday, May 22, 2023, at 2:59:14 PM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Clark at rmsc.com (cmcculloch@rmsc.com), with multiple recipients copied. The CC list included cwelch@rmsc.com, Jessa Galosmo at jessa@whaleylawfirm.com, Justin Chumbley at justin@whaleylawfirm.com, and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

In the body of the email, Whaley states that he is in receipt of Clark’s denial of the claim. He notes that Clark asserts the basis for denial is that his client “was confused on what transpired.” Whaley argues that Brenda Lang was not confused about what happened; rather, she was confused about where Clark’s driver came from, since that driver turned in front of her. He adds, “If someone turned right in front of me I might be confused as to where they came from as well.” Whaley then asks whether Clark’s vehicle has a camera, suggesting that such a camera might resolve the dispute, and he asks for a response. The message ends with thanks.

The email is signed by Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address listed as 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and the phone number 502-583-4022.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang MVA-09-03-2021. The client is Brenda Lang, and the file reference for the motor vehicle accident is 410220052.

Between May 22 and May 23, 2023, Brenda Lang’s counsel, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, engaged in a sequence of email exchanges with Clarke McCulloch, Property & Casualty Claims Manager. The May 22, 2023 correspondence began with Aaron acknowledging receipt of a denial on the claim and challenging the basis for denial. He stated that the basis claimed—that his client was “confused on what transpired”—was inaccurate, explaining that Brenda was not confused about what happened, but rather about where the service driver came from since the driver turned in front of her. He asked whether the vehicle had a camera, suggesting that such footage could possibly resolve the dispute, and asked for a reply.

In Clarke McCulloch’s May 22, 2023 reply, he indicated that the incident involved a service truck belonging to the Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD). He noted the truck was not equipped with a camera. He stated that both the driver and passenger attested that they had a green light and that Brenda Lang ran the red. He added that any evidence to the contrary would be taken into consideration.

On May 23, 2023, at 2:58 PM, Aaron sent another message to Clarke. He wrote: “Clarke, I do not consider a passenger in the vehicle to be a disinterested third party. As a practical matter trying hard not to be partisan, what do you think is more likely? A person brazenly runs a red light or a person turns right on red (which they are legally allowed to do) and just doesn't see the person coming?” This message was part of continuing discussion about liability and the available evidence.

The May 23 message also includes the earlier May 22 correspondence from Aaron, which reiterated his questions and concerns and requested information about whether the service vehicle had a camera to help resolve the dispute. The email chain shows Aaron Whaley’s law firm details (Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022) and the standard law firm signature, along with the partial contact list and file reference 410220052.

In summary, the exchange documented that the case centers on a collision involving a service truck from LMPD, which reportedly had no camera, with both the driver and passenger claiming they had a green light and Brenda Lang running a red; Brenda’s counsel sought to understand the opposing view, questioned the potential influence of a passenger as a non-disinterested party, and repeatedly asked whether a camera existed to resolve the dispute.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
In the Brenda Lang motor vehicle accident matter (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), relating to claim number 410220052, counsel exchanged a series of emails on May 22–23, 2023. The participants included Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, communicating with Clarke McCulloch of the insured’s representatives, with CC copies to Chris Welch, Jessa Galosmo, Justin Chumbley, and a filevine email for Brenda Lang’s matter.

On May 22, 2023 at 2:59 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Clarke McCulloch, with Chris Welch, Jessa Galosmo, Justin Chumbley, and the Brenda Lang Filevine address copied, attaching the subject “410220052.” In the email, Whaley acknowledged receipt of Clarke’s denial and stated that Clarke’s basis was that his client was “confused on what transpired.” Whaley contended that the confusion was about where Clarke’s driver came from, noting that if someone turned right in front of his client, she might be confused about their origin as well. He asked whether Clarke’s vehicle had a camera, suggesting that a camera could potentially resolve the dispute, and requested a response. The message concluded with Whaley’s signature block, including his firm’s contact information: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Later that evening, Clarke responded on May 22, 2023 at 6:22 PM. He explained that the incident involved a service truck belonging to the Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) and that the vehicle was not equipped with a camera. Despite this, he stated that both the driver and passenger attested they had a green light and that “your client ran the red.” He added that any evidence to the contrary would be taken into consideration. This response was followed by Clarke’s standard title and contact details.

The following day, May 23, 2023, at 2:58 PM, Whaley replied to Clarke (with the same CC recipients and subject line). He argued that a passenger in the vehicle should not be considered a disinterested third party. He framed the question in terms of likelihood, asking Clarke to consider what was more probable: “A person brazenly runs a red light or a person turns right on red (which they are legally allowed to do) and just doesn't see the person coming?”

At 3:28 PM on May 23, 2023, Clarke sent another response reiterating the core issue. He described the matter as “really a very simple matter,” noting that there were two drivers each claiming a green light at an intersection where only one could have had the green. He stated that the other vehicle sustained significant damage and that Whaley’s side had not issued a demand against Ms. Lang because the burden of proof lay with the claimant, and there was no evidence proving that Clarke’s client had the green light. He added that now Whaley represents the claimant, and the claimant bears the same burden of proof, and he posed the question, “How do you prove that we ran the red light?” The email concluded with Clarke’s signature, identifying him as Property & Casualty Claims Manager.

Finally, on May 23, 2023 at 3:31 PM, Whaley wrote back to Clarke (with the same CC list and subject). He stated: “Clarke, testimony is proof. It would be up to the jury who to believe. They could believe based upon your driver and passenger that Ms. Lang ran the light. They could believe Ms. Lang that your insured turned right on red.” This message continued the discussion about how the testimony of the participants could be interpreted by a jury.

The chain also included Clarke’s prior note from May 22, emphasizing that the service truck involved did not have a camera and that the driver and passenger had attested to a green light, as well as Whaley’s earlier assertion that the client was not confused about what happened but rather about where Clarke’s driver came from. The correspondence consistently referenced claim number 410220052 and involved the ongoing strategic dispute over which party had the right-of-way at the intersection and how best to prove who ran the red light.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative covers Brenda Lang’s motor vehicle accident case ( Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), specifically claim number 410220052, based on correspondence from May 22–23, 2023 between Brenda Lang’s counsel and the insurer’s representative. The underlying accident occurred on September 3, 2021, and involved Lang as the claimant against a Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) service truck. The accident diagram referenced in the discussion shows Lang’s vehicle damage at the 1:00 position (passenger front) and the other vehicle’s damage at the 11:00 position (driver front). The police report does not specify who struck whom. The service vehicle in question was described as a Ford F-450, nearly 20 feet long and weighing over four tons.

On May 23, 2023 at 7:00 PM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm wrote to Clarke McCulloch, the Property & Casualty Claims Manager for the opposing insurer, noting Lang’s view that the other driver “didn’t get very far into his turn before the impact,” and that the report does not identify who hit whom. Whaley emphasized that Lang’s client had no time to see a 20-foot-long vehicle and stated that he had litigated similar cases before and was prepared to litigate again. He also noted that there is more than one way to approach these cases and that he was comfortable with either path.

Clarke McCulloch later responded, pointing out that the police report indicates Unit #1 (Lang) stated the same about her approach but appeared confused about where Unit #2 (the truck) came from. He highlighted that the truck—a Ford F-450—was nearly 20 feet long and weighed over four tons, and that Lang hit it. He questioned how she could be confused about where a vehicle this large came from unless she wasn’t paying attention, and he suggested that missing the color of the light could also be easy in this scenario. He described the situation as “most likely,” but admitted he could not prove it and would need proof to support a claim. He said they were willing to review any evidence establishing the light color but would not agree to pay a claim when the only participants have opposing accounts and the only witnesses are two non-disinterested third parties.

In a subsequent message, Whaley argued that testimony is proof and that a jury would decide whom to believe. He stated that the jury could credit either the driver and passenger who said Lang ran the light or Lang’s version that the insured turned right on red.

Earlier in the thread, Clarke had stated that this was a simple matter: two drivers, both claiming they had a green light at an intersection where only one could have had the green. The insurer’s vehicle suffered significant damage, but no demand had been issued against Lang because the burden of proof lies with the claimant. Now that counsel represents the claimant, the same burden applies, and the question remains how to prove that the other party ran the red light.

Clarke had previously informed Whaley that the service truck belonged to LMPD and was not equipped with a camera, but that both the driver and passenger attested that they had the green light and that Lang ran it. He added that any evidence to the contrary would be considered.

Whaley responded by noting that he did not regard a passenger in Lang’s vehicle as a disinterested third party. He asked for Clarke’s view on what is more likely: a person brazenly running a red light or a person turning right on red and simply failing to see the other vehicle. He also asked whether Clarke’s vehicle had a camera, suggesting that camera evidence could resolve the dispute, and asked Clarke to let him know.

Across the exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the absence of disinterested third-party witnesses, the lack of camera evidence on the LMPD service truck, and the competing accounts of the accident. The communications reflect ongoing efforts to determine liability and the potential value of light-color evidence, with both sides signaling willingness to review new evidence but remaining cautious about accepting liability without additional proof.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang, a client in a motor vehicle accident matter filed as Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The file notes indicate the underlying accident occurred in early September 2021, with references to the date 09/04/2021 in communications and a case name that uses 09-03-2021.

The correspondence centers on what the firm needed from Brenda Lang and updates on document delivery. On Friday, May 19, 2023, at 4:18 PM, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm emailed Brenda Lang. The message requested that Brenda send, to the firm, a list of the medical providers she had treated with regarding the accident and a copy of her health insurance card (front and back). Jessa signed the message as All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm, and included the firm’s contact information: Ph: (502) 357-9975 and Fax: (502) 364-9363.

The record shows Brenda Lang replied on Tuesday, May 23, 2023, at 6:27 AM, but the content of that reply isn’t shown in the note. The thread then shows Brenda again engaging on June 5, 2023, with a message noted as coming from Brenda Lang at about 8:48 PM: “Checking with you this morning to see if your office received my USB drive.”

Later on June 5, 2023, at 21:01:50 +0800, Jessa Galosmo sent a response to Brenda Lang. The body of Jessa’s message stated, “I haven't received any update yet. I'll do a follow up today.” This email was sent from Jessa Galosmo (jessa@whaleylawfirm.com) to Brenda Lang (brndlang010@gmail.com) with the subject line Re: Whaley Law Firm.

For completeness, the note includes the firm’s standard signature blocks, which show the sender as Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm with the same phone and fax numbers listed above.
episodes.author: Jessa

This note concerns Brenda Lang’s motor vehicle accident case filed in Jefferson Circuit Court. The case caption is LONG, BRENDA D. VS. HAMLET, MARCUS ET AL, and the case number is 23-CI-005515. The file is labeled Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The electronic filing in question was submitted for Envelope 6555977 by Aaron Gregory Whaley, an attorney for the plaintiff, representing the Whaley Law Firm.

On September 13, 2023, at 11:20:53 a.m. Eastern, the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system rejected the envelope. The clerk’s note stated: “error processing please resubmit in new envelope.” No payment was collected for this eFiling; eFiling transactions are preauthorized at the time of envelope submission but are not finalized until clerk acceptance, and payment will be required upon resubmission of the envelope. The notice was sent to Whaley, Aaron Gregory (agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com), along with Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and Bryce@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and there were no scheduled events associated with this filing.

The envelope included the following documents: COMPLAINT / PETITION: PERSONAL INJURY COMPLAINT - MVA, and EXHIBIT: EXHIBIT 1 - LMPD POLICE REPORT. Additional details provided in the notice include links for further action: https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Dashboard/Receipt?caseid=6555977 to view dashboard/receipts, https://kcoj.kycourts.net/eFilingRetrieval/Home/Package?id=FF5D9D89-5ACF-4DE2-A3A9-D7D16ABA99D3 to view the documents, and https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Filing/?parentId=6555977 to file subsequent case matters.

episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the Brenda Lang motor vehicle accident case, listed as Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, in Jefferson Circuit Court under case number 23-CI-005756, captioned LANG, BRENDA VS. HAMLET, MARCUS ET AL. The matter was being pursued by Aaron Gregory Whaley, attorney for the plaintiff. On September 20, 2023, at 3:20 PM Eastern, the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system returned the envelope for the submission identified as Envelope #6606273. The return notice, sent by noreply@kycourts.net, indicated that the submission had been denied due to an error in processing the envelope: a clerk’s note stated that an attachment within the submitted envelope was corrupt and instructed the filer to flatten (Print to PDF) all documents and resubmit.

The clerk’s note further specified that the items must be resolved and resubmitted to the Circuit Clerk by September 22, 2023, at 11:59 PM Eastern. No payment was collected for this eFiling. The eFiling system notes that transactions are preauthorized at the time of envelope submission but are not finalized until clerk acceptance; payment will be required upon resubmission.

The eFiler for this submission was Aaron Gregory Whaley, attorney for the plaintiff. The submission was intended for the Jefferson Circuit Court (Circuit). The case caption again reads LANG, BRENDA VS. HAMLET, MARCUS ET AL, with Case Number 23-CI-005756 and Envelope Number 6606273. The notice was electronically mailed to Whaley, Aaron Gregory, at agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

There were no scheduled events for this submission. The documents included in the eFiling were: COMPLAINT / PETITION: MVA COMPLAINT, and EXHIBIT: EXHIBIT 1 - LMPD POLICE REPORT. Additional details provided with the notice included a link to the eFiling dashboard receipt (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Dashboard/Receipt?caseid=6606273) and a link to view the document package (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/eFilingRetrieval/Home/Package?id=D2AB4964-1992-419D-BC6E-8FCB3FC20A9C). There is also a link to file subsequent case matters (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Filing/?parentId=6606273).

The notice concludes by stating that this message was automatically generated by the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system and that recipients should not reply to the email. A Kentucky Court of Justice Confidentiality Notice accompanies the message, indicating that the content and any attachments are confidential, privileged, and/or proprietary work product, and providing instructions if the recipient is not the intended recipient.

In summary, the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet et al case's eFiled documents (MVA Complaint and LMPD Police Report Exhibit 1) were rejected due to a corrupt attachment. The filer is required to flatten the documents and resubmit by September 22, 2023, at 11:59 PM Eastern, with payment due upon resubmission, and no payments having been collected with this initial submission.

episodes.natural_language:
Case Brenda Lang-MVA-09-03-2021 involves Brenda Lang in a motor vehicle accident that occurred on September 3, 2021. The client is Brenda Lang.

Brenda Lang has received a letter of representation from Allison L. Rief of the law firm Dilbeck & Myers, who serves as defense counsel for the mother’s claim against Brenda Lang. The note indicates that the letter of representation is being sent to Allison. The entry is tagged as Lit, CrossComplaint, and CDC.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

law firm of the attorney sending representation letter

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on September 3, 2021 with Brenda Lang regarding a motor vehicle accident.

According to the note from staff member Stuttle, the client called in asking to speak with you, but your line was busy earlier, so I told her I would relay her concern to you and that you could call her back. The client said she had received a letter from an attorney and needs guidance on what to do with it.
episodes.author: Jessa

about.relevance: initial contact; called about receiving an attorney letter and seeking guidance

__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 15 2023
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on November 15, 2023, with Brenda Lang regarding the motor vehicle accident case Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The client left a voicemail asking whether we had received any letters from her defense counsel, Dilbeck & Myers, whom she identifies as her defense counsel since her mother—the passenger—has filed suit against her and Defendant Hamlet. Sarena, the person making contact, is checking in with AW and BK before returning the client's call.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021
Client: Brenda Lang

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Checked in w/BK - He has not received anything from DC - Checked CourtNet for update - DC Lou Metro filed MTD - Case is noted as on Hold until 12/01/2023 - Possibly awaiting Objections to MTD - Called Client - She received a packet from DC Reif - Wanted to confirm she is actually her attorney as well - Confirmed for Client that Mrs. Reif is there to help her against her mothers case - Client Advised Mother's Attorney dropped her case - advised will discuss with AW & BK to see if we can help mother get new counsel 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 15 2023
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on November 15, 2023 with Brenda Lang regarding a motor vehicle accident case (MVA) dated 09-03-2021. The outreach, conducted by Sarena, included checking in with BK, who stated he has not received anything from DC. CourtNet was checked for updates; DC Lou Metro filed an MTD, and the case is noted as on hold until December 1, 2023, possibly awaiting objections to the MTD.

During the contact, Brenda Lang reported she had received a packet from DC Reif and wanted to confirm that Reif is her attorney. I confirmed that Mrs. Reif is there to help her with her mother’s case. Brenda advised that her mother’s attorney had dropped her mother’s case and said she would discuss with AW and BK to see if we can help her mother obtain new counsel.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

about.relevance: attorney for client's mother / discussed as counsel
docket system checked for case status (case on hold until 12/01/2023)

episodes.original_body:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021
Client: Brenda Lang

@bryce3 @aaronw Spoke with Client this morning - Winton & Hiestand have dropped mother's case & are withdrawn as of 11/09/2023 (Jeff Cir Crt 23-CI-005662) - Mother is 90 something years old - Claim still in progress - Due to conflict of interest we can not take on but Can we refer mother to someone?

Our case is on hold DC Lou Metro (Gowen) file Motion to Dismiss - Case Noted on Hold until 12/01 - Do we need to file objections to Motion to Dismiss?
episodes.natural_language:
This morning I spoke with Brenda Lang regarding her motor vehicle accident case, identified as Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Winton and Hiestand have dropped the mother’s case and are withdrawn as of November 9, 2023 (Jeff Cir Crt 23-CI-005662). The mother is in her nineties. The claim remains in progress. Due to a conflict of interest, we cannot take on the mother’s case, but we would like to know whether we can refer the mother to another attorney.

Our case is currently on hold in the DC Lou Metro (Gowen) file regarding a Motion to Dismiss. The case is noted on hold until December 1, 2023. Should we file objections to the Motion to Dismiss?
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

about.relevance: client whose case was withdrawn; referral requested
court where the mother's case withdrawal was recorded

episodes.natural_language: Case Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021 involves client Brenda Lang in a motor vehicle accident matter dated September 3, 2021. The actions were tagged in the file as Lit, AliasSummons and Lit, Service.

Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville sent an email to Scott Gowen and Aaron Whaley, with Sarena Tuttle copied, regarding the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet case. The subject line read Re: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. In the body of his message, Koon stated that the discovery materials had been received and that they would be returned promptly. He signed the message with his contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 364-9363. Earlier that same day, at 8:52 a.m. Eastern Time, Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Gowen, Scott cc’d. The subject line read Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. episodes.natural_language:
Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet is a motor vehicle accident case filed under the file Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, with Brenda Lang as the client. The correspondence summarized here involves discovery in the case and exchanges between Brenda Lang’s counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen, a Louisville official, with several parties copied on the messages.

On February 12, 2024, at 8:52 a.m., Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, cc’ing himself, in which he attached discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in Word and PDF formats. He asked Aron Whaley and Bryce Koon to confirm receipt of the attachments. The message was titled Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, and the body requested confirmation of receipt. The email carried a confidentiality notice stating that the information was confidential, intended solely for the named recipient, and that disclosure or distribution to others was prohibited. The message included the standard notice about attorney‑client privilege and instructed recipients who were not the intended recipients to contact the sender and not to use or forward the information.

Later that same day, at 9:18 a.m., Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) responded: “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” His reply carried his firm’s standard confidentiality notice, identical in substance to the prior message, noting that the message was intended for the named recipient and protected by privilege.

On April 9, 2024, at 11:02:17 a.m. -0400, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., again of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a follow-up email to Scott Gowen regarding Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. The message was titled Re: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet and was sent from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com to scott.gowen@louisvilleky.gov, with Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com cc’d. In the body, Koon stated that after reviewing his file, it did not appear that the recipient’s client’s discovery responses had been received yet and asked when they could be expected. He expressed appreciation for Scott Gowen’s assistance in the matter. The signature block provided the following contact details: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, Phone: (502) 365-5043, Fax: (502) 364-9363. The email again included the standard confidentiality and privilege notices warning that the message is intended only for the named recipient and should not be shared with unauthorized individuals.

In all communications, the disclosures included the standard confidentiality notices common to these emails, stating that the information is confidential, intended solely for the named recipient, may contain attorney-client privileged information, and that if the message was received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding it.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, the client is Brenda Lang, in the matter of Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle accident case. The communications summarized below concern discovery, exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm, representing Brenda Lang, and Scott Gowen of Louisville/Jefferson County government.

On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon with the subject Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in Word and PDF format and asking for confirmation of receipt. The message indicated that Scott had attached discovery requests for Ms. Lang, and he requested that the recipients confirm receipt. The email was cc’d to Scott Gowen and included a confidentiality notice typical of such communications, noting that the information is confidential and privileged and should not be shared with unintended recipients.

Later that same day, February 12, 2024 at 9:18 a.m., Bryce Koon, Esq., responded: “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” This reply, like the initial message, carried a standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer and contact information for The Whaley Law Firm.

On April 9, 2024, at 11:02 a.m., Bryce Koon sent an email to Scott Gowen with the subject Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. In the body, he wrote: “Good morning Scott, After reviewing my file, it does not appear we have received your client’s discovery responses yet. Could you please let us know when we may expect such responses? Your assistance in this matter is greatly appreciated.” The message was cc’d to Sarena Tuttle and to BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The signature block identified W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and listed the phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax number (502) 364-9363. This email also bore the firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer, indicating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any disclosure or forwarding by unintended recipients could be unlawful or a waiver of privilege.

In sum, there was a February 12, 2024 exchange in which discovery requests were forwarded to Brenda Lang’s counsel (and acknowledged as received), followed by a separate April 9, 2024 inquiry from Brenda Lang’s counsel requesting an expected timeline for the opposing party’s discovery responses.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), serving as the plaintiff, Brenda Lang, the discovery correspondence unfolded between February and April 2024. The matter was treated as a motor vehicle accident case (MVA), and the client was Brenda Lang.

On February 12, 2024, at 8:52 a.m., Scott Gowen, counsel for the Louisville Metropolitan Government, sent an email to W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and Aaron Whaley with discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer. The discovery requests were attached in Word and PDF format. Gowen asked for confirmation of receipt and copied Sarena Tuttle and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com on the communication. The message included the confidentiality disclaimer typical of such emails.

Later that same day, at 9:18 a.m., Bryce Koon replied. He acknowledged receipt of the discovery requests and stated that they would be returned promptly. His reply included the standard confidentiality notice and caution that the email originated outside Louisville Metro, advising recipients not to click links or forward the content if received in error. Koon's signature contained his firm’s contact details.

Before this February exchange, Gowen’s initial note to the defense team was explicit about attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer; he asked the recipients to confirm receipt and again included the confidentiality disclaimer in his message.

Several weeks later, on April 9, 2024, additional correspondence occurred. At 11:02 a.m., Bryce Koon wrote that, after reviewing his file, it did not appear that the defense had received the client’s discovery responses yet and asked Scott Gowen to indicate when those responses might be expected. The message carried the outside-mail caution and the standard confidentiality disclaimer, with Koon’s usual contact information in the signature.

That afternoon, at 3:53 p.m., Gowen responded. He requested, in turn, to have until the end of the month to serve the responses and apologized for the oversight and delay.

Less than an hour later, at 4:04 p.m., Koon replied to Gowen with a short, accommodating acknowledgment: “Scott, That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me.” This message also carried the standard confidentiality notice.

Throughout these exchanges, the emails consistently included confidentiality language noting attorney-client privilege and instructing that, if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information. The communications involved the principal participants—W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, representing Brenda Lang, and Scott Gowen, representing the Louisville Metropolitan Government—with Sarena Tuttle cc’d on the messages and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com also included in the CC field.

Case: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021). Client: Brenda Lang.

In February 2024, discovery was being circulated between counsel. On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm, with Sarena Tuttle copied, attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in both Word and PDF formats and asking for confirmation of receipt. The message also carried a confidentiality disclaimer stating that the information was confidential and intended only for the named recipients. Earlier that same morning (8:52 AM), Gowen had sent a similar note requesting receipt confirmation for the Word and PDF discovery documents.

Later that day, at 9:18 AM, Bryce Koon replied: “Received. We will get these back to you promptly,” indicating acknowledgment of receipt. His reply also included the standard attorney‑client confidentiality disclaimer common to the firm’s correspondence.

On April 9, 2024, the discovery process appeared unsettled. At 11:02 AM, Bryce Koon sent an email noting that, after reviewing his file, the firm did not appear to have received the client’s discovery responses yet and asking when they could be expected, expressing appreciation for Scott Gowen’s assistance. Later that same day, at 7:53 PM UTC, Gowen replied: “Bryce, May I please have until the end of this month to serve the responses? I apologize for the oversight and delay.” Bryce’s April 9 message also carried a caution stating that the email came from outside Louisville Metro and advising caution with links or attachments.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The file concerns Brenda Lang in the motor vehicle accident case Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, with Brenda Lang as the client.

In February 2024, a sequence of discovery-related emails unfolded between counsel for Brenda Lang and the City of Louisville’s representatives. On Monday, February 12, 2024, at 8:52 a.m., Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Scott Gowen cc’d, regarding the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter. He attached the discovery requests for Ms. Lang in both Word and PDF formats and asked the recipients to confirm receipt. The subject line was Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. The message included a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the information is confidential and intended only for the recipient, and warning that any disclosure or action in relation to the contents by others is prohibited.

At 9:18 a.m. on the same day, Monday, February 12, 2024, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, replied: “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” His message included his law firm’s contact information and the same attorney‑client privilege disclaimer as part of the signature block.

Later that same day, the February 12 email thread shows additional correspondence from Bryce Koon at 11:02 a.m. in a separate entry, continuing the same discussion about discovery. The request remained that the discovery responses be provided, and the message again carried the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On Friday, February 12, 2024, at 9:18 a.m. (the earlier February 12 message with Bryce’s reply preceded this timestamp in the record), Scott Gowen also sent a message indicating that he had attached discovery requests in Word and PDF for Ms. Lang to answer and requested confirmation of receipt. The message carried the confidential‑disclaimer language as part of the chain.

Moving to April 2024, on Tuesday, April 9, 2024, at 11:02:17 a.m., Bryce Koon sent another message to Scott Gowen with the subject RE: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. In this email, Bryce wrote that after reviewing his file, it did not appear that the client’s discovery responses had been received yet, and he asked when they could be expected. He again included the standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer in his email signature block.

Later that same day, at 3:53 p.m., Tuesday, April 9, 2024, Scott Gowen replied to Bryce’s earlier message. He asked for until the end of the month to serve the responses and apologized for an oversight and delay. He signed with his name and included the “Get Outlook for iOS” mobile signature line. The message was accompanied by the same confidentiality disclaimer.

Finally, at 4:04 p.m. on Tuesday, April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon responded to Scott Gowen with, “Scott, That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me.” His message again included his standard firm signature and the attorney‑client privilege disclaimer.

Across these exchanges, the participants included W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363) and Scott Gowen (associated with Louisville Metro), along with Sarena Tuttle (cc’d) and the file-specific recipient address BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com (cc’d in the communications). Each email contained the customary confidentiality and privilege notices advising that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any inadvertent receipt should be reported to the sender, with no waiver of privilege.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This note concerns the matter Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle accident case. The correspondence below reflects email communications between Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen, with Brenda Lang copied, related to taking depositions in the case.

On July 2, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an email to Scott Gowen (cc: Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address) regarding the planned deposition of the client. The subject was Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. In the message, Koon stated that they would like to take their client’s deposition and asked Gowen to provide some dates in mid-late August that would work for both sides. The email carried a caution about external email: “CAUTION: This email came from outside of Louisville Metro. Do not click links, open attachments, or give away private information unless you recognize the sender's email address and know the content is safe.” It also included the standard confidentiality notice, explaining that the information was intended only for the named recipient and that disclosure or action based on the contents could be unlawful if you were not the intended recipient. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information appeared in the signature: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207.

On July 5, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM, Gowen replied that he would like to depose Ms. Lang as well and that both depositions should be able to be completed on the same day. He requested 2–3 dates in late September when he and Ms. Lang would be available. Gowen stated that once he had those dates, he would coordinate with Mr. Hamlet to schedule the depositions.

Later that same day, on July 5, 2024 at 11:18:34 AM, Bryce Koon responded: “Sounds good Scott. I will get back to you shortly with some dates. Thank you.” This message was sent after Gowen’s reply, and the thread continued to discuss scheduling, with the original subject remaining Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet.

The correspondence included the standard email disclaimers regarding confidentiality and attorney-client privilege, and the messages were distributed to and from The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen, with Brenda Lang cc’d via the Filevine project email address.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This note memorializes the correspondence in the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter, with the latest activity reflecting scheduling discussions in July 2024 and earlier discovery-related exchanges in February and April 2024.

In a July 15, 2024 email, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Scott Gowen’s address and to Bryce Koon at The Whaley Law Firm. She stated that her office had wide availability for September and could accommodate nearly any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after October 10. She asked Gowen to provide a more narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client. The email included Tuttle’s contact details, noting a new email address, and was dated 1:16 PM Eastern Time.

Turning to the earlier communications, on February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent an email to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley, with Sarena Tuttle copied, attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in both Word and PDF formats and asking for confirmation of receipt. The email included the standard confidentiality notice customary for such communications, advising that the message and attachments are privileged and should not be forwarded if received in error.

Later that same day, Bryce Koon replied, acknowledging receipt of the discovery requests and stating that they would be returned promptly. This exchange was part of the ongoing discovery process in the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet case.

Earlier still, on February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen had requested confirmation of receipt for the attached discovery requests, and Bryce Koon had confirmed that they would be responsive in due course. The chain also included an earlier note from Gowen on the same day indicating that the discovery requests were attached in Word and PDF format and asking for receipt confirmation, with the usual confidentiality disclaimers accompanying the message.

An additional thread from April 9, 2024 shows a two-part exchange regarding the timing of service of discovery responses. At 3:53 PM, Gowen asked Bryce Koon for an extension to the end of the month to serve the responses, apologizing for an oversight and delay. Bryce replied at 11:02 AM that, after reviewing his file, it did not appear that the client’s discovery responses had yet been received, and he asked for a timeline for when such responses could be expected. Gowen then responded later that afternoon, indicating that the requested extension was acceptable. The exchange included the standard caution and attorney-client privilege notices typical of these communications.

In sum, the case note captures a sequence of discovery-related exchanges between The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel in early 2024, culminating in a July 2024 scheduling inquiry from Sarena Tuttle confirming available dates in September and after October 10, and preserving the records of prior discovery requests, receipt confirmations, and an extensionrequest discussion.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case caption Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle accident matter labeled Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, the client is Brenda Lang. This note chronicles a series of communications between counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen, an attorney for the opposing side, along with related correspondence within The Whaley Law Firm.

On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in both Word and PDF formats. He asked for confirmation that the recipients had received the attachments. Later that same day, at 8:52 AM, Gowen followed up with another email to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley, confirming that the discovery requests were attached and requesting receipt confirmation. At 9:18 AM, Bryce Koon replied, stating that he had received the discovery requests and that they would be returned promptly.

On February 12, 2024, at 9:18 AM, Bryce Koon sent a reply confirming receipt and promising to return the discovery responses promptly. The thread continued with Gowen’s earlier message at 8:52 AM noting the attached discovery requests and his request for receipt confirmation. The February 12 exchanges were followed by standard confidentiality notices typical of such communications.

A later exchange occurred on April 9, 2024. At 3:53 PM, Scott Gowen wrote to Bryce Koon asking if he could have until the end of the month to serve the discovery responses, apologizing for an oversight and delay. In response, at 11:02 AM the same day, Bryce Koon acknowledged Gowen’s request by stating that, after reviewing the file, it did not appear that the opposing side’s discovery responses had yet been received and asked when those responses could be expected. A short reply from Bryce, sent later that day around 4:04 PM, stated, “That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me,” indicating that the proposed extension was acceptable.

Separately, on April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon’s earlier message was accompanied by the standard caution about external email security. The thread also includes the Whaley Law Firm’s signature and contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial  (D) 502-357-9971; office line  (O) 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (note indicates a new email address).

Finally, on July 15, 2024, at 1:16 PM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Scott Gowen with the subject Re: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. In this message, she indicated that her office had substantial availability in September and could accommodate almost any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after the 10th. She asked Gowen to provide a more narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client. Sarena’s message includes her contact information and a note highlighting her new email address. The email was copied to Bryce Koon and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

Together, these communications outline the discovery requests and corresponding responses timeline (February 12, 2024; April 9, 2024) and a scheduling inquiry for September 2024, reflecting ongoing coordination between The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel regarding the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter.

episodes.natural_language:
In the motor vehicle case Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), the client is Brenda Lang and the matter involves communications between The Whaley Law Firm and counsel for Marcus Hamlet, with supporting materials copied to the Louisville City Attorney’s Office. The notes document discovery exchange and deposition scheduling activities.

Beginning in February 2024, Scott Gowen of the opposing side sent discovery requests to Brenda Lang’s counsel. On February 12, 2024, Gowen attached the discovery requests in Word and PDF format and asked for confirmation of receipt. That same day, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm replied, acknowledging receipt with “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” The correspondence list shows that Gowen’s February 12, 2024 message was copied to Aaron Whaley and to the Brenda Lang filevineapp address, with Sarena Tuttle also copied.

Later on February 12, 2024, Bryce Koon again confirmed receipt of the discovery requests, reiterating that the firm would return them promptly. The earlier message from Gowen to Bryce on February 12, 2024, at 8:52 AM had indicated that the discovery requests were attached and requested confirmation of receipt, and Bryce’s subsequent reply at 9:18 AM confirmed receipt and promised prompt action.

On April 9, 2024, a brief back-and-forth occurred regarding the discovery responses. Bryce Koon sent a message stating that, after reviewing his file, it did not appear that they had yet received the client’s discovery responses; he asked when such responses could be expected. Gowen replied later the same day, requesting an extension to the end of the month to serve the responses and apologizing for the oversight and delay. A cautionary note about the external origin of the email was included in the message thread, and Bryce’s earlier reply on the same day acknowledged the inquiry.

In July 2024, the parties again addressed scheduling. On July 15, 2024, the Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Mr. Gowen noting that dates to depose Brenda Lang had been requested on July 15 but no response had been received. They requested that Gowen provide available dates for deposing Lang. Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, signed the message and provided her contact information, including her new email address. The firm’s signature listed The Whaley Law Firm’s mailing address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line (502) 357-9971 and main line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the address as the new email). The note also shows that Gowen was copied on the communication, along with the BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com address.

A follow-up message from Sarena Tuttle, dated the same day, stated that the Whaley Law Firm’s calendar was fairly open for September and that they could accommodate nearly any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after the 10th; she asked Gowen to provide a more narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client.

An automatic reply was generated in this matter from Scott Gowen, whose email is Scott.Gowen@louisvilleky.gov, and the message was sent to Sarena Tuttle at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. The auto-reply is titled “Automatic reply: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet” and the date of the message is Tuesday, August 27, 2024, at 19:40:08 UTC.

In the body of the reply, it states: “I am currently out of the office, but will be checking email daily. If your message is time sensitive, please call my cell phone at 502.693.1941.” The message then includes a confidentiality notice: “The information contained in this communication from the sender is confidential. It is intended solely for use by the recipient and others authorized to receive it. If you are not the recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, copying, distribution or taking action in relation of the contents of this information is strictly prohibited and may be unlawful.”
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. The correspondence concerns the Brenda Lang motor vehicle accident matter, with Scott Gowen representing the plaintiff and The Whaley Law Firm representing the defense, in communications spanning February through August 2024 regarding discovery responses and the scheduling of depositions.

On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley discovery requests for Ms. Lang in both Word and PDF formats, asking them to confirm receipt. The message was cc’d to Sarena Tuttle and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and included a confidentiality/privilege disclaimer. Bryce Koon replied later that same morning, 9:18 AM, acknowledging receipt and stating that they would get the discovery responses back promptly, also including the standard attorney-client privilege notice.

Later, on April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon replied to Gowen at 11:02 AM (with a caution about external email sources). He noted that, after reviewing the file, it did not appear they had yet received the client’s discovery responses and asked for an update on when those responses could be expected. Gowen responded in the afternoon at 3:53 PM, requesting until the end of the month to serve the responses and apologizing for the oversight and delay.

In mid-February 2024, the exchange also included the Whaley Firm’s standard legal correspondence and disclosures. The February 12, 2024 messages contained a disclaimer indicating the email’s privileged status and a reminder that the message is intended only for the named recipients; similarly, the later April 9 communications included such notices.

On July 15, 2024, at approximately 1:16 PM (the exact minute is indicated as 1:16?PM in the record), Sarena Tuttle wrote to Mr. Gowen with respect to deposition scheduling. She indicated that their office was fairly open for September and could accommodate just about any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after October 10, requesting that Gowen provide a more narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client.

By August 27, 2024, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Gowen (2:39:45 PM) noting that, in July 2024, they had requested deposition dates for Brenda Lang but had not yet received a response. She asked Gowen to provide dates on which his client would be available to be deposed. Gowen replied later that day (20:04:45 UTC), apologizing for the lapse, explaining that he was out of town that week, and promising to supply deposition dates the following week.

These exchanges trace the ongoing discovery timeline and deposition scheduling efforts in Brenda Lang’s case against Marcus Hamlet, with discovery requests issued in February 2024, a pending response as of April 2024, and deposition scheduling discussions continuing through August 2024, including a promise to provide availability dates after Gowen’s return from travel.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang.

In the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter, the communications presented here reflect ongoing discovery and deposition scheduling efforts between The Whaley Law Firm, representing Brenda Lang, and Scott Gowen, counsel for Marcus Hamlet. The Whaley firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, Sarena M. Tuttle, sent and received multiple emails in early 2024 with scheduling requests, responses, and confirmations, and the file includes standard confidentiality notices and a note noting Sarena’s new email address.

On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent discovery requests for Ms. Lang to be answered, attaching the requests in Word and PDF formats and asking Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon to confirm receipt. He also requested that the recipients let him know when they would respond. In response, Bryce Koon replied later that same day, confirming receipt of the discovery requests and that they would be returned promptly. This exchange was part of a longer thread that also included a message from Gowen noting that the discovery requests were attached and requesting receipt confirmation, along with the standard attorney-client confidentiality notice that accompanies such correspondence.

Earlier still in the same thread, Bryce’s February 12 message reiterated that they had received the discovery requests and would get them back promptly. The communication from Gowen and the follow-up reply from Bryce were accompanied by the firm’s confidentiality disclaimer, which warned that the material is intended for the named recipient and that disclosure or forwarding to others is prohibited.

On April 9, 2024, there was further discussion about the timing of producing responses. Scott Gowen asked for permission to have until the end of the month to serve the discovery responses, apologizing for an oversight and delay. Bryce Koon responded that this arrangement was acceptable and thanked Gowen for the update. Later that day, Gowen sent a follow-up message reiterating the request to extend to the end of the month to serve the responses, and Bryce again acknowledged.

In the subsequent chronology, there is a separate thread concerning deposition dates. On July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Mr. Gowen noting that their office was fairly open in September and that they could accommodate nearly any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after September 10th, asking Gowen to provide a narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client. On August 27, 2024, Gowen apologized for losing track of the scheduling and explained that he was out of town that week but would provide deposition dates the following week. Earlier on July 15, 2024, Sarena had already requested dates to depose Brenda Lang, and on August 27, 2024, she reiterated that they had not yet received a response to the July 15 deposition-date request.

That same August 27, 2024 email thread shows Sarena following up at 2:39:45 PM with a reminder that, on July 15, 2024, dates to depose Ms. Lang were requested and that no response had been received; she asked Gowen to provide dates when Brenda Lang could be deposed. The email included a caution note indicating the message came from outside Louisville Metro and warning recipients not to click links or open attachments unless the sender’s address and content were familiar and safe. Gowen replied at 4:04 PM that he was sorry for letting it drop off his radar, that he was out of town that week, and that he would provide some deposition dates the following week.

The record also reflects the usual disclaimers placed on The Whaley Law Firm emails, including confidentiality notices and notices that the electronic messages are intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details are: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; main office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email for Sarena Tuttle: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; and a note that this is a new email address. The firm’s standard closing also identifies Bryce Koon, Esq., with the same address and phone numbers.

In sum, the file documents discovery-response scheduling activity in February and April 2024, with an extension discussion in April, followed by deposition-scheduling attempts beginning in July 2024 and a responsive acknowledgment from Gowen in August 2024, including reminders that a deposition date coordination had not yet been provided and that Gowen would supply available dates soon. The communications preserve all known facts and details from the cited exchanges, including the participants, the dates of the messages, the requested and agreed-upon extensions, the deposition-date requests, the reminders, and the confidentiality notices.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang.

The Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet case, concerning a motor vehicle accident in September 2021, progressed through a series of discovery and deposition scheduling communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Louisville government counsel. The latest thread begins with an email dated September 4, 2024, from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to Scott Gowen. In that note, she says they are circling back on the matter from the prior week and asks Mr. Gowen to provide deposition dates as soon as he is settled back in. She also references the deposition of Brenda Lang and requests dates that her client can be deposed. The message includes her contact details and notes her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and phone lines D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104. Cc’d on the thread are Bryce Koon and a filevine application email for Brenda Lang’s matter, and the email shows the subject line “Re: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet.” The message concludes with a typical sign-off and her job title.

Prior to that, on August 28, 2024 at 9:43 AM, Sarena wrote to Gowen: “Good morning Mr. Gowen, We completely understand. Thank you for the update,” followed by her signature and contact information, including the new email address. 

The preceding exchange shows Gowen’s response from August 27, 2024 at 4:04 PM, in which he apologized for letting the matter drop off his radar and explained that he was out of town that week but would provide deposition dates the following week.

Earlier still, on August 27, 2024 at 2:39:45 PM, Sarena had sent a message (with a standard outside-email caution) noting that, as of July 15, 2024, they had requested dates to depose Brenda Lang and had not yet received a response. She asked Gowen to provide dates when his client would be available to be deposed and again signed her name with the firm’s contact information and her new email address.

The July 15, 2024 communication from Sarena stated that The Whaley Law Firm’s schedule was fairly open in September, with availability on most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th, and she asked Gowen to provide a narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client at that time.

Moving back to an earlier segment of the record, on April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon replied to Scott Gowen with a brief acceptance: “That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me.” Bryce signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the Louisville address and contact details.

Earlier that same day, April 9, 2024 at 3:53 PM, Gowen had written to Bryce requesting an extension to serve the responses, asking for until the end of the month to serve the responses and apologizing for the oversight and delay.

At 11:02 AM on April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon had sent a caution-laden email indicating that the message came from outside Louisville Metro and encouraging the recipient to exercise caution with links and attachments. In that message, Bryce stated: after reviewing his file, they had not yet received the client’s discovery responses and asked when such responses could be expected.

The chain also contains longer, earlier exchanges from February 2024. On February 12, 2024 at 8:52 AM, Scott Gowen wrote to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, forwarding discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer in Word and PDF formats and asking for confirmation of receipt. The message includes a standard confidentiality notice. Bryce Koon replied later that day, February 12, 2024 at 9:18 AM, confirming receipt and stating that they would “get these back to you promptly.” The thread also shows the earlier February 12, 2024 exchange in which Gowen had initially attached the discovery requests to a message to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon and asked for confirmation of receipt, with the same confidentiality language included.

In summary, the case involved ongoing discovery and deposition scheduling efforts between The Whaley Law Firm and the counsel for Marcus Hamlet, with repeated requests for available deposition dates for Brenda Lang, responses and extensions for discovery, and a back-and-forth chain of communications spanning February through September 2024. The most recent communication, dated September 4, 2024, again requests deposition dates and notes that the team is awaiting Mr. Gowen’s availability after his return.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The client in this matter is Brenda Lang, with the case file labeled Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021.

In this sequence of communications, The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel exchanged multiple emails regarding deposition dates and discovery responses related to Brenda Lang’s motor vehicle accident case against Marcus Hamlet. The first noted exchange in the record occurred on February 12, 2024, when Gowen, Scott sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, attaching discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer and asking them to confirm receipt. Bryce Koon replied later that same day, acknowledging receipt and stating that they would return the discovery materials promptly.

On April 9, 2024, the matter advanced to scheduling and responses. Scott Gowen sent a message asking for until the end of the month to serve the responses and apologizing for the oversight and delay. Bryce Koon responded later that morning, indicating that, after reviewing his file, they had not yet received the client’s discovery responses and asking when the responses could be expected. The exchange included standard attorney-confidentiality disclaimers, noting that the electronic messages were intended for the named recipients and contained privileged information, with reminders to contact the sender if received in error.

Earlier correspondence in February 2024 also included a back-and-forth about the discovery requests. Gowen had attached in Word and PDF format several discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer and asked for confirmation of receipt, and Bryce Koon confirmed receipt and pledged prompt handling.

Jumping roughly to mid-2024, on July 15, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, wrote that their office was fairly open for September and could accommodate most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th, and asked Gowen to provide a narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client.

The scheduling efforts continued into August. On August 27, 2024, Gowen replied that he was out of town that week but would provide deposition dates the following week. That same day, Sarena Tuttle sent a message to Gowen, noting that on July 15, 2024 they had requested dates for deposing the client and that they had not yet received a response; she asked him to provide dates when Brenda Lang’s deposition could occur. Her message circulated with the caution that the email originated outside Louisville Metro and included the standard disclaimer about external emails. The message also listed the contact details for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (502) 357-9971; office line (502) 583-4022 ext. 104; and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to note the new email address.

On August 28, 2024, Sarena Tuttle again wrote to Gowen, opening with a greeting and saying, “Good morning Mr. Gowen,” and stating that they completely understood and thanking him for the update, indicating ongoing communication about scheduling and deposition dates.

Finally, on September 4, 2024, at 11:34:44 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle reached back out to Gowen, referencing the message from the previous week. She noted that she hoped he had enjoyed his trip and had time to get caught up, and she urged him to provide the deposition dates as soon as he was settled back in.

Throughout these communications, the parties remained focused on securing deposition dates for Brenda Lang’s deposition and on handling discovery responses, with multiple attempts to confirm receipt, coordinate schedules, and adjust timelines, all while maintaining the standard confidentiality disclosures and the contact details for The Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the deposition scheduling and related discovery communications in the matter of Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle accident case (MVA) with the file label Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The client is Brenda Lang and the correspondence involves The Whaley Law Firm, represented by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and Scott Gowen, with the Louisville group.

In February 2024, the Whaley firm began follow‑up on discovery. On February 12, 2024, Bryce Koon replied to Gowen, noting that “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” Earlier that day, Gowen had corresponded with Aaron Whaley regarding the matter. Later on that same day, Gowen sent a separate note to Bryce and others, and Bryce reiterated the need for timely discovery responses. A parallel thread shows Gowen asking for additional time to provide the discovery responses; on April 9, 2024, Gowen requested until the end of the month to serve the responses, and Bryce responded the following day, stating that they would get back to him promptly and that they had not yet received the responses.

From mid‑April through July 2024, the parties discussed scheduling depositions. On July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle wrote that The Whaley firm’s calendar in September was fairly open and that they could generally accommodate most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th. She asked Gowen to provide a narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client. In a subsequent exchange, Gowen replied on July 15 that they would review dates; by July 27, Sarena noted that they had not yet received dates and reiterated the request for available deposition dates. On August 27, 2024, Sarena reminded Gowen that dates to depose his client had been requested on July 15 and again asked him to provide dates that Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet could attend. Gowen responded later that day, explaining that he had been out of town and would provide dates the following week. On August 28, 2024, Sarena acknowledged the update.

As September approached, Gowen proposed a deposition date. On September 4, 2024, Gowen suggested September 18 as a deposition date: he could depose Brenda Lang beginning at 9:00 a.m., with Bryce Koon deposing Marcus Hamlet immediately afterward, and he offered to host. In response, Sarena noted that their office was pretty booked for September but could be available on any day after October 1. She closed with a courteous message indicating appreciation for the update and confirming the new availability timeline.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties exchanged standard external-email cautions and signatures. The Whaley Law Firm signatures included their office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact details for Sarena Tuttle (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noted as the new email address) and Bryce Koon (D/Fax numbers as listed in the chain). A note within the emails repeatedly emphasized that the message and attachments are intended for the named recipient and may contain privileged information.

In summary, by early September 2024 the parties had discussed deposition dates for Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet, with September 18 proposed but contingent on the availability of scheduling, while the Whaley firm communicated that their September calendar was largely booked, with open availability only after October 1. The exchange reflects ongoing efforts to coordinate deposition logistics and to finalize discovery-related timing in this case.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, Brenda Lang, arising from a motor vehicle accident on September 3, 2021. The matter proceeded through a series of discovery and deposition scheduling communications in 2024 among Scott Gowen, counsel for Brenda Lang; Sarena Tuttle, the Whaley Law Firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager; and Bryce Koon, also with The Whaley Law Firm, with Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet as the parties.

On February 12, 2024, Scott Gowen sent discovery requests for Ms. Lang to answer, delivering them in Word and PDF format and asking Bryce Koon to confirm receipt. Bryce replied at 9:18 a.m. that the requests had been received and that they would be returned promptly. Earlier, Gowen had noted that the email containing the discovery materials was confidential and intended only for the named recipient. On the same day, Gowen followed up asking for confirmation of receipt.

A few weeks later, on April 9, 2024, Bryce informed Gowen that they had not yet received Ms. Lang’s discovery responses and asked when they could be expected. Gowen responded later that day, at 3:53 p.m., requesting and apologizing for the delay, and asking for until the end of the month to serve the responses.

Progress toward depositions stalled for several months. On July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle told Gowen that The Whaley Law Firm’s office was open the month of September and that they could accommodate deposition dates on most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after October 10, requesting that Gowen provide a more narrowed set of dates that would work for his client.

The discussion resumed activity between July and August. On August 27, 2024, at 2:39 p.m., Sarena reminded Gowen that they had requested dates to depose his client back on July 15 and had not yet received any dates indicating when Brenda Lang would be available to be deposed. Gowen replied later that day at 4:04 p.m., explaining that he was out of town that week and would provide dates the following week. The following day, August 28, Sarena responded, acknowledging the situation and thanking Gowen for the update.

By early September, the parties were moving toward setting a deposition. On September 4, 2024, at 11:34:44 a.m., Sarena again requested deposition dates as soon as Gowen was settled back in. Later that day, at 5:07:30 p.m. (UTC), Gowen replied with a proposed date: September 18. He stated that he could depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 a.m. and that Bryce Koon could depose Mr. Hamlet immediately after; Gowen also offered to host the deposition.

Throughout this correspondence, the chain of messages shows ongoing coordination among the involved attorneys and staff, including the Whaley Law Firm’s updates to Sarena about new email addresses—Sarena Tuttle’s address is noted as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a reminder to note the new email address in the firm’s communications—and the exchange of discovery materials and deposition scheduling between February and September 2024. The CC list for these communications included Bryce Koon and the BrendaLangMVAZ3760694 filevine email, reflecting the case’s administrative tracking.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This matter is Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, with The Whaley Law Firm representing Brenda Lang. The principal contacts shown in the record include Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct lines are D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext. 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address). The recipient in the correspondence is Scott Gowen of Louisville, Kentucky, with copies to Bryce Koon and to an account associated with Brenda Lang’s File Vine app.

In the first relevant exchange, dated September 4, 2024, the sender (Sarena) closed with a message indicating that their schedule for September is largely booked, but that they are available any day after October 1. This update followed an inquiry from Scott Gowen about scheduling depositions.

Earlier that same day, at 1:07 PM, Gowen had written proposing a deposition on September 18, starting at 9:00 AM for Ms. Lang, with Bryce deposing Mr. Hamlet immediately afterward, and offering to host the deposition himself. The message was part of a back-and-forth thread discussing deposition logistics.

In the preceding messages, there is a longer thread beginning in February 2024. On February 12, 2024, Bryce Koon, Esq. stated, “Received. We will get these back to you promptly,” indicating a response to discovery demands. By April 9, 2024, Scott Gowen requested more time to serve discovery responses, asking for the end of that month. Bryce Koon replied that, after review, it did not appear the client’s discovery responses had yet been received and asked for a timeline. Gowen replied that the extension to the end of the month was acceptable. Bryce acknowledged the arrangement.

The timeline continued with a July 15, 2024 exchange. Sarena Tuttle informed Gowen that, on July 15, 2024, they had requested dates to depose his client and had not yet received a response. She asked Gowen to provide dates when his client would be available to be deposed. She also noted that their office was fairly open in September and could accommodate most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th, requesting a narrowed set of dates that would work.

On August 27, 2024, Gowen responded from out of town, apologizing that he had not yet provided deposition dates but that he would supply some dates the following week. Sarena replied on August 27, 2024, at 2:39:45 PM, reiterating that they had requested deposition dates on July 15 and had not yet received a response, and asking for availability. Gowen followed up later that afternoon with an apology for the delay and explained he was out of town. Sarena acknowledged the situation on August 28, 2024, thanking him for the update and expressing understanding.

Following these exchanges, on September 4, 2024, at 11:34:44 AM, Sarena again pressed Gowen to provide deposition dates as soon as he and his client were able to settle back in. Later that same day, at 1:07 PM, Gowen replied with a concrete proposal: September 18 as the deposition date, with Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 AM and Bryce deposing Mr. Hamlet immediately after, and he stated he was happy to host. In response, at 1:45:20 PM, Sarena informed Gowen that their schedule for September was largely booked, but they were available any day after October 1.

Across the thread, the communications consistently revolve around scheduling depositions for Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet, with separate depositions for Lang and Hamlet, the possibility of the defendants appearing for deposition, and the logistics of hosting. The notes reflect repeated attempts to coordinate dates from mid-2024 through early September 2024, including discussions of discovery responses and deposition timing, as well as the constraint that, as of early September, the team’s calendar was full in September and open only after October 1.

In summary, the case Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet involved ongoing discovery-related correspondence beginning in February 2024, with several back-and-forth exchanges about the timing of discovery responses and the scheduling of depositions. The latest documented proposal (September 18, 2024) was for Ms. Lang to be deposed at 9:00 AM, with Mr. Hamlet’s deposition to follow, hosted by Gowen, but the client’s side indicated September was fully booked and that availability would begin after October 1.
