episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle accident case filed on September 3, 2021, involving client Brenda Lang. The following narrative summarizes the deposition-scheduling exchanges in the “RE: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet” email thread, centered on the participation of Scott Gowen (emailing from Scott.Gowen@louisvilleky.gov), Sarena Tuttle (The Whaley Law Firm), and W. Bryce Koon (The Whaley Law Firm) regarding Ms. Lang and Mr. Hamlet.

The thread begins with an exchange in early 2024 about discovery responses. On February 12, 2024, Bryce Koon (W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm) replied to Scott Gowen, noting, “Received. We will get these back to you promptly.” Earlier, on April 9, 2024, Gowen asked for more time to serve the discovery responses, writing, “Scott Gowen: May I please have until the end of this month to serve the responses? I apologize for the oversight and delay.” In response, Bryce Koon commented that, after reviewing his file, they had not received their client’s discovery responses yet and asked when they might be expected. The exchange also shows a standard attorney-client privilege notice included in Bryce’s messages.

The deposition scheduling conversation then shifts to July and August 2024, when The Whaley Law Firm requested dates to depose their client and did not receive a timely response. On July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle stated that their office was pretty open for September and requested dates for deposing the other side’s client, Brenda Lang’s deposing party, and to provide dates that the other side’s client is available. On August 27, 2024 at 2:39 PM, Sarena followed up again, noting, “On July 15, 2024, we requested dates to depose your client & unfortunately, we still have not received a response. Can you please provide dates that your client is available to be deposed?” Scott Gowen replied later that day, saying he was out of town and would provide dates the following week. The next day, August 28, 2024, Sarena replied, “Good morning Mr. Gowen, We completely understand. Thank you for the update.” The thread later shows ongoing attempts to pick dates, with the parties seeking times that work within their calendars.

On September 4, 2024, two messages in the thread show renewed focus on deposition dates. At 11:34:44 AM, Sarena again reached out: “Good afternoon Mr. Gowen, We are just circling back on this one from last week. We hope that you enjoyed your trip and have had some time to get caught up. Please provide us with those deposition dates as soon as you're settled back in.” Gowen responded at 1:07 PM: “Will September 18 work? I can depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 and Bryce can depose Mr. Hamlet immediately after. I am happy to host.” At 1:45 PM, Sarena replied that they were booked for September but open any day after October 1st.

Finally, on September 5, 2024, at 18:52:57 UTC, Gowen proposed an alternative date: Friday, October 25. He wrote, “How about Friday, October 25? I can depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 a.m. and Bryce can depose Mr. Hamlet immediately thereafter. Again, I am happy to host. Please let me know if this works for you guys and I will get a notice out.” This exchange completes the latest scheduling attempt in the thread, with The Whaley Law Firm indicating October 1st or later openings and Gowen offering to host.

Throughout the email chain, the deposition subjects remained Ms. Lang ( Brenda Lang) and Mr. Hamlet ( Marcus Hamlet), with the attendees being Ms. Lang across the table from Gowen and Mr. Hamlet from Bryce Koon’s side, and the depositions described as to occur at Gowen’s hosted location, contingent on the dates agreed.

Other contextual notes from the thread include the recurring caution banners indicating that some emails originated outside Louisville Metro, cautioning recipients about clicking links or opening attachments from unfamiliar addresses. The Whaley Law Firm is identified with the following contact details in the thread: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS”). The Whaley Law Firm’s client contact for the opposing side is reflected as Bryce Koon, Esq., with the firm’s address listed similarly and the firm’s typical disclaimer about privileged information appended to messages. The opposing counsel, Scott Gowen, is connected to the Louisville government (as indicated by the Scott.Gowen@louisvilleky.gov address in the thread).

In sum, the parties engaged in a protracted dialogue across multiple months (from February through September 2024) to schedule depositions for Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet, with September 18 being proposed, then October 1 as a post-September window, and finally October 25 as a proposed deposition date, all while acknowledging scheduling conflicts and Gowen’s willingness to host and issue a notice if the other side confirms.

episodes.natural_language:
The matter is Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, a motor vehicle collision case arising from a 2021 incident (MVA 09-03-2021), with Brenda Lang represented by The Whaley Law Firm and Marcus Hamlet by Louisville city attorney Scott Gowen. Over the summer and fall of 2024, the parties exchanged multiple emails to schedule depositions. The plaintiff’s team included Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, who also provided a new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com) and listed The Whaley Law Firm’s office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line (502) 357-9971 and office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104. The defendant’s side involved Scott Gowen (Scott.Gowen@louisvilleky.gov) and W. Bryce Koon, Esq. (Bryce@whaleylawfirm.com). Several emails included the standard caution banner stating that the message came from outside Louisville Metro.

In April 2024, the parties began discussing discovery and deposition logistics. On April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon noted that it did not appear the defendant had served discovery responses yet and asked when they could expect them. Scott Gowen replied later that day requesting until the end of the month to serve the responses, apologizing for the delay. Earlier that day, Bryce had asked about the status of the discovery responses as well.

By mid-July 2024, the issues began to shift toward scheduling depositions. On July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle wrote that their office was fairly open for September and could accommodate most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after October 10, requesting a narrowed set of dates that would work for the opposing side. She reiterated that September was tight but opened up after October 1 if needed.

Toward the end of August 2024, there was further back-and-forth about dates. On August 27, Scott Gowen apologized for losing track of the matter due to being out of town and said he would provide dates the following week. A day later, on August 28, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged Gowen’s note and explained that, while they were pretty booked for September, they were open any day after October 1.

In early September, the parties continued to discuss possible deposition dates. On September 4, 2024, Gowen proposed September 18 as a potential deposition date, with Ms. Lang to be deposed first beginning at 9:00 a.m. and Mr. Hamlet to be deposed immediately afterward, with Gowen offering to host the deposition. In response, Sarena acknowledged the request and noted that they were regrouping after travel, but she reiterated that they remained booked for September and would be open after October 1.

Finally, on September 5, 2024, Gowen proposed Friday, October 25, as the deposition date. He suggested that Ms. Lang be deposed first at 9:00 a.m., followed immediately by Bryce Koon deposing Mr. Hamlet, and that Gowen’s office would again host. He also stated that a notice would be sent. That plan was confirmed later that same day by Sarena, who wrote, “That sounds perfect. Oct 25, 2024 starting at 9am w/PL immediately followed by Def at your office. We will get a notice over to you as well. Thank you so much.”

Throughout these exchanges, the involved attorneys and staff—Sarena M. Tuttle (The Whaley Law Firm), Scott Gowen (Louisville, KY), and Bryce Koon (The Whaley Law Firm)—worked to coordinate deposition dates and logistics. The notes also include the various iterations of contact details and reminders to send notices, along with the signatures and new email address for Sarena.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), the parties exchanged a series of emails in 2024 concerning deposition dates for Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet, with The Whaley Law Firm representing Brenda Lang and Scott Gowen handling the deposition logistics on the opposing side.

On September 5, 2024, Scott Gowen sent Sarena Tuttle a note attaching his notice to depose Brenda Lang. In the message, he said that, by copy of the email to court reporter Wendy Cotton, he was requesting that she cover the deposition of Ms. Lang. He also added that Wendy could be told to cover Mr. Hamlet’s deposition if desired. The initial email to Sarena and Bryce Koon also included copies to BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and to Wendy Cotton, with the time stamped 19:50:07 +0000.

Later on September 5, 2024 at 3:13 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied. She indicated that the arrangement sounded perfect and stated that on October 25, 2024, starting at 9:00 AM, the deposition of Brenda Lang would occur with the Plaintiff’s deposition immediately followed by the Defendant’s deposition at Gowen’s office. She also said they would send a notice as well.

That same day, at 2:53 PM, Gowen wrote back proposing an alternative on October 25: he suggested that Lang be deposed on Friday, October 25, beginning at 9:00 AM, with Bryce deposing Mr. Hamlet immediately afterward. He reiterated that he was happy to host and asked for confirmation that the date and plan would work so he could issue a notice.

Earlier on September 4, 2024, Sarena had written Gowen noting that their office was pretty booked for September, but open any day after October 1. She signed with her Whaley Law Firm contact information, including the new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

In a September 4, 2024, 1:07 PM exchange, Gowen had suggested September 18 as a possibility, stating he could depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 AM and that Bryce could depose Mr. Hamlet immediately after, and that he was happy to host. Sarena acknowledged this in a later message.

Before that, on September 4, 2024 at 11:34:44 AM, Sarena had reminded Gowen that deposition dates were needed soon and asked him to provide them as soon as he was settled back in. She reiterated her contact information and noted the new email address.

A week earlier, on August 28, 2024 at 9:43:00 AM, Sarena had told Gowen that they understood and thanked him for the update, continuing the thread about scheduling.

On August 27, 2024, Gowen had replied at 4:04 PM that he was out of town that week but would provide dates the following week. Earlier that same day at 2:39 PM, Sarena replied to Bryce Koon (with Gowen and BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com CC’d) noting that, on July 15, 2024, they had requested dates to depose Brenda Lang and that they had not yet received a response; she asked for dates that the client was available to be deposed.

The thread also shows a prior sequence beginning on July 15, 2024, when Sarena wrote that their office was open for September and that they could look at just about any Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday after the 10th, asking for a narrowed set of dates that would work for the other side.

Even earlier, on April 9, 2024, Bryce Koon had observed that, after reviewing his file, it did not appear they had received Brenda Lang’s discovery responses yet and asked when they may be provided. Scott Gowen replied later that day, asking for until the end of the month to serve the responses, apologizing for the oversight and delay. A separate portion of the chain on April 9, 2024 included Bryce’s signature block with standard attorney-file disclosures.

In sum, the record reflects a back-and-forth spanning April through September 2024, focused on scheduling Brenda Lang’s deposition (and the related deposition of Marcus Hamlet), with proposed dates including September 18, 2024; October 25, 2024 (Lang at 9:00 AM with Hamlet afterward); and the arrangement that a court reporter, Wendy Cotton, would cover Lang’s deposition, and potentially Hamlet’s as well. The scheduling discussions were conducted between The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle and Bryce Koon) and Scott Gowen, with various CC addresses and the plaintiff’s file references, and included notices and hosting arrangements at Gowen’s office.

In September 2024, the parties continued to coordinate depositions in the motor vehicle accident matter involving Brenda Lang. The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle and Scott Gowen, with Bryce Koon in copy, exchanged a series of emails, and notices were prepared to be filed via CourtNet. The deposition notices were to be covered by court reporters, with Wendy Cotton (Wendy Cotton, listed in correspondence) identified to cover Lang’s deposition, and each side was invited to arrange coverage for the other side’s deposition if desired.

The exchange began with a July 15, 2024 email in which Sarena Tuttle noted that their office was open for the month of September and that they could consider most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th. She asked Scott Gowen to provide a narrowed set of dates that would work for him and his client. This message indicated a fairly open window for scheduling depositions but without firm dates yet.

On August 27, 2024, Gowen apologized for the delay and said he was out of town but would provide dates the following week. In a contemporaneous email, Sarena pointed out that, since July 15, 2024, they had requested dates to depose Brenda Lang’s client, and they still had not received a response; she asked Gowen to provide dates when his client would be available to be deposed. Gowen acknowledged the lag and promised to supply dates next week. A few days later, on August 28, 2024, Sarena responded with a polite acknowledgment: they understood Gowen’s update.

Moving into September, the week of September 4, 2024, Gowen proposed September 18 as a deposition date, indicating he could depose Ms. Lang starting at 9:00 a.m., with Bryce to depose Mr. Hamlet immediately afterward, and noting he was happy to host the depositions. The Whaley firm replied on the same day, September 4, 2024, at 1:45 p.m., with cautionary language about outside emails. The message expressed thanks and explained that they were pretty booked for September but were open on any date after October 1.

Earlier that same day, September 4, 2024, at 11:34:44 a.m., Sarena had written back, indicating they were circling back on the matter from the previous week and asking Gowen to provide deposition dates as soon as he was settled back in.

On September 5, 2024, Gowen suggested October 25 (Friday) as a deposition date, proposing Lang’s deposition beginning at 9:00 a.m. with Bryce deposing Mr. Hamlet immediately thereafter, and he reiterated his willingness to host. Sarena responded later that day (September 5, 2024, at 3:13 p.m.) that October 25, 2024, starting at 9:00 a.m., with Lang (the plaintiff) first and Hamlet (the defendant) immediately after, at Gowen’s office, would work; she noted that they would provide a notice as well. She also included the caution that this email carried the standard outside-LOUISVILLE Metro notice.

Gowen then replied (September 5, 2024, at 2:53 p.m.) confirming the proposal and adding: he had attached his notice to depose Ms. Lang and, by copy to court reporter Wendy Cotton, asked that she cover Lang’s deposition; he invited them to let Wendy know if they wanted her to cover Hamlet’s deposition as well.

The next day, September 6, 2024, Sarena replied: their notice was attached as well and would be filed via CourtNet. Her note also included the Whaley Law Firm contact information: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a reminder to note the new email address.

In sum, the communications document an ongoing, back-and-forth process to schedule the depositions of Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet for October 25, 2024. The plan was for Lang’s deposition to begin at 9:00 a.m., followed immediately by Hamlet’s deposition, with Scott Gowen hosting the deposition at his office. Notices to depose were to be filed with CourtNet, and Wendy Cotton was to cover Lang’s deposition (with the possibility of covering Hamlet’s deposition upon request). The parties also indicated the depositions would be conducted with the plaintiff Lang first and the defendant Hamlet second, and the notices would be issued promptly. The correspondence spanned July 15, 2024, through early September 2024, and included multiple cautions about outside-email content and standard procedural notices.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This is a sequence of email communications in the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter, focusing on scheduling deposition dates for Ms. Lang and Mr. Hamlet and the related notices and court-ordered coverage.

The exchange begins with a back-and-forth of deposition planning via The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen. On April 9, 2024, at 3:53 PM, Gowen wrote to Bryce Koon asking, “How about Friday, October 25? I can depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 a.m. and Bryce can depose Mr. Hamlet immediately thereafter. Again, I am happy to host. Please let me know if this works for you guys and I will get a notice out.” Bryce replied at 4:04 PM, saying, “Scott, That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me.” The transmission included standard attorney-client privilege notices from Bryce Koon.

Moving forward to July 15, 2024, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent a message noting that, on July 15, 2024, they had requested deposition dates to depose Brenda Lang and, unfortunately, had not yet received a response. She requested dates that Mr. Gowen’s client would be available for deposition and specified a preference for dates in September, given their scheduling needs.

By August 27, 2024, Gowen acknowledged the lapse and explained he was out of town that week but would provide dates the following week. In a reply sent the same day, August 27, 2024 at 2:39 PM, Sarena reiterated that they had requested deposition dates on July 15 and had not yet received a response, urging Gowen to provide dates for his client’s deposition.

Gowen responded again on August 27, 2024 at 4:04 PM, apologizing for the delay and indicating he would furnish dates next week. The next day, August 28, 2024 at 9:43 AM, Sarena replied, saying, “Good morning Mr. Gowen, We completely understand. Thank you for the update.”

On September 4, 2024, at 11:34 AM, Sarena followed up with Gowen, noting they were “circling back” on the deposition scheduling from the previous week and asking Gowen to provide deposition dates once he had settled back in. Gowen replied on September 4, 2024 at 1:07 PM, proposing, “Will September 18 work? I can depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 and Bryce can depose Mr. Hamlet immediately after. I am happy to host.”

Sarena’s response came later that day, September 4, 2024 at 1:45 PM, stating, “Thank you so much. We are now pretty booked for September, however, we are open any day after October 1st.” Her signature followed, detailing The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; noting the email address as a new address.

Gowen then proposed a specific alternative on September 5, 2024 at 2:53 PM: “How about Friday, October 25? I can depose Ms. Lang beginning at 9:00 a.m. and Bryce can depose Mr. Hamlet immediately thereafter. Again, I am happy to host. Please let me know if this works for you guys and I will get a notice out.” Sarena responded at 3:13 PM the same day, writing, “That sounds perfect. Oct 25, 2024 starting at 9am w/PL immediately followed by Def at your office. We will get a notice over to you as well. Thank you so much.” Her message also included the Whaley Law Firm signature with the same contact details.

By September 5, 2024 at 3:50 PM, Gowen attached his deposition notice to Ms. Lang and, by copy of the email to court reporter Wendy Cotton, requested that she cover Lang’s deposition and asked that Wendy be informed if she should cover Hamlet’s deposition as well. Sarena confirmed the arrangement in a follow-up message on September 6, 2024 at 9:49:04 GMT-04:00, stating, “Thank you so much Mr. Gowen, Our notice is attached as well and will be filed via CourtNet momentarily.” Her signature again listed The Whaley Law Firm’s address, phone numbers, and her new email address.

Across these exchanges, the parties advanced a plan to depose Brenda Lang on October 25, 2024 at 9:00 a.m., with Marcus Hamlet to be deposed immediately thereafter at Gowen’s office, and with The Whaley Law Firm preparing and filing deposition notices via CourtNet. The discussions also touched on the involvement of the court reporter Wendy Cotton to cover Lang’s deposition and the possibility of coverage for Hamlet’s deposition, as directed by Gowen. The correspondence consistently referenced the need for depositions to occur in Louisville, with the parties coordinating host arrangements and notice delivery in the weeks leading up to the proposed date.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang.

This document records the sequence of email communications regarding the deposition schedule in Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet. The exchange began in 2024 and involved The Whaley Law Firm, specifically Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and W. Bryce Koon, Esq., along with Scott Gowen, who appears to be counsel for the defendant, Marcus Hamlet. The parties discussed dates for deposing Brenda Lang (the plaintiff) and Marcus Hamlet (the defendant), with hosting arrangements and notices to be issued.

On September 5, 2024, at 3:12 p.m. Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Scott Gowen, with Bryce Koon and Brenda Lang’s filevine email included in copy. In her message she stated, “That sounds perfect. Oct 25, 2024 starting at 9am w/PL immediately followed by Def at your office. We will get a notice over to you as well. Thank you so much.” She signed as Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line 502-357-9971 and office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and noted her new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The message was accompanied by her professional signature.

Earlier on the same day,  Scott Gowen replied at 2:53 p.m., proposing a deposition on Friday, October 25, with Ms. Lang to be deposed at 9:00 a.m. and Bryce Koon to depose Mr. Hamlet immediately thereafter. Gowen stated he was happy to host and asked to be advised whether the date worked so he could issue a notice.

The thread also contains the preceding exchanges, beginning with Gowen’s September 4, 2024, 1:07 p.m. inquiry in which he asked whether September 18 would work, offering to depose Ms. Lang at 9:00 a.m. and have Bryce depose Mr. Hamlet immediately after, noting his willingness to host. In response, on September 4, 2024, at 11:34 a.m., Sarena Tuttle wrote back to Gowen, addressing him as “Mr. Gowen,” explaining that they were circling back on the matter from the prior week and hoping he had enjoyed his trip. She asked him to provide deposition dates as soon as he was settled back in.

Earlier still, on August 28, 2024, at 9:43 a.m., Sarena Tuttle acknowledged Gowen’s update with, “Good morning Mr. Gowen, We completely understand. Thank you for the update.” And on August 27, 2024, at 4:04 p.m., Gowen responded that he was out of town that week and would provide dates the following week. In turn, on August 27, 2024, at 2:39 p.m., Sarena wrote that, as of July 15, 2024, they had requested dates to depose the defendant client and had yet to receive a response, asking Gowen to provide dates when his client would be available for deposition.

The chain shows a prior July 15, 2024 exchange in which Sarena noted the office was fairly open in September and could accommodate most Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays after the 10th, requesting a narrowed set of dates from Gowen. The thread also reflects an earlier line of communication from April 2024. On April 9, 2024, Gowen asked Bryce Koon for an extension, requesting until the end of the month to serve responses and apologizing for the oversight and delay. Bryce replied later that same day, at 11:02 a.m., that after reviewing the file it appeared they had not received Gowen’s responses and that they would follow up. Gowen then replied at 3:53 p.m. requesting until the end of the month to serve the responses, to which Bryce responded at 4:04 p.m. with an acknowledgment that it was acceptable (the exact wording in that message reads, “That is okay with me. Thank you for getting back to me.”).

Throughout these communications, multiple messages included the standard outside-sender caution banner indicating that the email originated outside Louisville Metro, advising recipients not to click links or open attachments unless the sender’s address and content were recognized as safe. These cautions appeared at various points in the threaded messages, including the September 4, 2024 and July 27–August 28, 2024 entries.

In sum, the record shows a protracted scheduling dialogue beginning in April 2024 and extending through September 2024, culminating in an agreed proposed deposition plan for October 25, 2024, with Brenda Lang’s deposition at 9:00 a.m., followed by Marcus Hamlet’s deposition immediately afterward, to be hosted at Gowen’s office, and with a notice to be issued to the opposing party. The participants consistently referenced coordinating notices, hosting arrangements, and the availability windows noted in their correspondence, while also noting periods when schedules were open or booked and the need to secure dates after October 1 and specifically targeting October 18, October 25, and other mid- to late-October slots as the case progressed.

Tuttle’s signature identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The phone numbers listed were D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating it was her new email address. The correspondence also shows that Bryce Koon and Greg Whaley were CC’d on the initial communications.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda Lang MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This narrative covers a new deposition submission linked to the Brenda Lang motor vehicle accident case.

On October 24, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, sent a new scheduling submission from 20 Second Scheduler regarding the Brenda Lang case. In her message, she indicated that the deposition would involve only the deposition of Defendant Hamlet, and she noted that Wendy McLaughlin from the defense had been cc’d on their notice. Her contact details were included: Sarena Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (with a note to use the new email address).

Earlier that same day, the Scheduling Department at Kentuckiana Reporters replied, asking for clarification: “Good morning! Are we also taking the depo of the plaintiff or just of Marcus Hamlet? Please advise.” This indicated that the team was unsure whether the plaintiff’s deposition would be included, and it referenced Marcus Hamlet as the defendant being considered for deposition.

The scheduling thread also displayed the Kentuckiana Reporters team’s standard contact information and policies. The Scheduling Team listed Kristina Calhoun, McKenna Watson, Rachel Walker, and Madison Elam, along with their phone number (502-589-2273), email (Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com), and address (730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202). They included a Cancellation Policy stating that a cancellation fee applies for assignments cancelled with less than 24 hours’ notice, and a note that interpreter requests cancelled within 24 hours of the appointment time will be billed at the industry standard of a 2-hour minimum rate.

A prior email from Kentuckiana Reporters dated September 6, 2024, 10:14 AM, addressed to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com, stated: “Got it! We’ll get this added to our calendar & re-confirm 24 hours prior to the deposition. Thanks! McKenna.” This shows ongoing coordination about adding the deposition to the calendar and scheduling a 24-hour confirmation.

Also on September 6, 2024, a message from donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com (on behalf of donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com) conveyed the deposition details from Sarena Tuttle: the “Additional Comments” read, “Def Depo will be at 1p or Immediately Following Plaintiff - Plaintiff scheduled to start at 9am.” A Notice to Take Deposition file was attached: NTTD-Def-Hamlet-10.25.24.pdf.

In sum, the depositions are scheduled for October 25, 2024, with the plaintiff’s deposition set to start at 9:00 AM and the defendant’s deposition for Defendant Hamlet to begin at 1:00 PM or immediately following the plaintiff, depending on the plaintiff’s timeline. The notice to take deposition for the defendant Hamlet is referenced as NTTD-Def-Hamlet-10.25.24.pdf.

For context, the case file and participants referenced in these communications include the following staff associates listed in the signature blocks: Kristina Calhoun, McKenna Watson, Rachel Walker, and Madison Elam. It provided Kentuckiana’s contact information (P: 502-589-2273; E: Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com; A: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202) and stated the Cancellation Policy: a cancellation fee will apply for all assignments cancelled with less than 24 hours’ notice, and interpreter requests cancelled within 24 hours of the appointment time will be billed at the industry standard of a 2-hour minimum.

Earlier that day, at 12:08 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied to Scheduling, informing them that she had confirmed with DC Gowen that everything was a go for tomorrow, and that Gowen anticipated the Plaintiff would require only one hour, with the Plaintiff’s appearance scheduled to start at 9:00 AM. Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, provided her contact details and noted her new email address: sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. Her signature also includes the firm’s Louisville address and direct lines.

An earlier note from Scheduling, dated around 9:33 AM on 10/24/2024, stated that the attached confirmation for tomorrow’s proceeding should be reviewed for accuracy or revised as needed, and requested an estimated duration if available. The email contained a check-box list with [X] Court Reporter selected, while the other options—Videographer, Interpreter, Conference Room, ZOOM Connection, and Telephone Conference—were not selected.

The final confirmation for 10/25/2024, dated 10/25/2024, lists the following details: TIME 1:00 PM Eastern Standard Time; CLIENT Aaron Whaley, Esquire; FIRM The Whaley Law Firm; CASE STYLE Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet; JUDGE/WITNESS Marcus Hamlet; LOCATION Office of Gregory Gowen (First Trust Centre), 200 S. Fifth Street, Suite 300N, Louisville, Kentucky. The message thanks the recipient for scheduling with Kentuckiana and includes a confidentiality notice stating that the information in the email is intended solely for the addressee and may contain privileged information, is subject to Federal Rules of Evidence 408, and may be exempt from disclosure under applicable law. Recipients should not file copies of this email with publicly accessible records, and if the reader is not the intended recipient or the employee or agent responsible for delivering the message to the intended recipient, dissemination, distribution, or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021
Client: Brenda Lang

Had client and defendant depos today. Client's depo went pretty poorly as she had a ton of trouble explaining how the collision occurred and changed her story a couple of times, at one point testifying that the vehicle in the damage photos was not the vehicle she collided with - very difficult. However, the Defendant testified that he could not remember anything about the collision (where he was coming from, going to, what street he was on when the wreck occurred). The police report and incident reports by driver and passenger contradict one another. Spoke to DC and said I would be sending over a demand soon. He candidly told me they would likely make a small offer but are not going to accept the appendectomy as related (2 days post-MVA). I told him I would send him over a demand with everything and we can talk numbers in the future.
episodes.natural_language:
In the case Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021, involving client Brenda Lang, the client and the defendant were deposed today. The client's deposition went pretty poorly, as she had a lot of trouble explaining how the collision occurred and she changed her story a couple of times; at one point she testified that the vehicle in the damage photos was not the vehicle she collided with.

The Defendant testified that he could not remember anything about the collision—specifically where he was coming from, where he was going to, or what street he was on when the wreck occurred. The police report and the incident reports by the driver and passenger contradict one another.

I spoke to DC and said I would be sending over a demand soon. He candidly told me they would likely make a small offer but are not going to accept the appendectomy as related (two days post-MVA). I told him I would send him over a demand with everything and we can talk numbers in the future.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

__Summary of the call with Brenda D. Long__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Brenda D. Long [BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Fri Jan 10 2025 11:40:54 GMT-05:00

Hi

Here's the summary of the call with Brenda D. Long at 1/10 11:30 AM
(UTC-05:00):

Brenda and Aaron discussed the challenges in proving the appendicitis was
related to the car accident, leading to a recommendation to negotiate a
settlement.

Recap

 * Aaron Whaley informed Brenda that the demand sent for her car accident
case has not been accepted due to difficulties in linking her appendicitis
to the accident.
 * The accident occurred on September 3rd, and Brenda went to the emergency
room two days later.
 * Aaron reviewed medical records and found insufficient evidence to prove
the appendicitis was caused by the accident, despite the timing.
 * Brenda acknowledged the truck hit her car but expressed frustration over
the opposing party's stance.
 * Aaron recommended starting negotiations with the other party, as
pursuing the appendicitis claim would likely be unproductive.
 * Brenda expressed gratitude for Aaron's support during this challenging
time, especially after losing her husband.

Tasks

 * Aaron needs to initiate negotiations with the opposing attorney
regarding the settlement offer.

Best,
aaron whaley
episodes.natural_language:
On January 10, 2025, at 11:30 AM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley spoke with Brenda Lang regarding her motor vehicle accident case. They discussed the challenges of proving that her appendicitis was related to the accident, and they agreed that pursuing a settlement would be advisable.

During the call, Aaron informed Brenda that the demand sent for her car accident case had not been accepted due to difficulties in linking her appendicitis to the accident. The accident occurred on September 3, 2021, and Brenda went to the emergency room on September 5, 2021. After reviewing her medical records, Aaron found insufficient evidence to prove that the appendicitis was caused by the accident, despite the timing. Brenda acknowledged that a truck hit her car but expressed frustration with the opposing party's stance. Aaron recommended starting negotiations with the other party, as pursuing the appendicitis claim would likely be unproductive. Brenda expressed gratitude for Aaron's support during this challenging time, especially after losing her husband.

As a next step, Aaron needs to initiate negotiations with the opposing attorney regarding the settlement offer. Best, Aaron Whaley.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Brenda Lang’s motor vehicle accident case (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021) involves a claim arising from a crash in which Brenda Lang was struck by a truck and subsequently developed appendicitis. The central issue in the case is proving that the appendicitis was caused by the accident, which is the main challenge currently facing the matter. In the last 30 days, the most recent activity was a telephone discussion between attorney Aaron Whaley and Brenda D. Long. During that call, they talked through the difficulties of linking the appendicitis to the accident and they agreed that negotiating a settlement would be the recommended next step.

A potential risk to the case is the lack of sufficient evidence to prove that the appendicitis was caused by the accident, a gap that could significantly impact the settlement amount and may lead to a lower settlement than initially anticipated. The next recommended step is for Aaron Whaley to initiate negotiations with the opposing attorney regarding the settlement offer, focusing on the aspects of the case that can be proven.

From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Gowen, Scott [scott.gowen@louisvilleky.gov](mailto:scott.gowen@louisvilleky.gov)
Cc: Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address [BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Mon Jan 27 2025 12:17:24 GMT-05:00

Good afternoon Mr. Gowen,

I hope this email finds you well. Attached, please find a revised
settlement demand for the above-referenced matter.

As you will see, we have removed all references to the appendix-related
issues and treatment. While we continue to believe there were valid
questions regarding the connection of those issues to the collision, we
recognize the difficulty in litigating such matters. This removal is
intended as a showing of good faith to help facilitate a resolution in this
case.

Even with those items removed, Ms. Lang has incurred more than $26,000 in
medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by your client's
negligence. As such, an offer in the range of $5,000-10,000 will not be
sufficient to resolve this matter.

We remain willing to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the
documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang's pain and suffering. Please let
us know your client's position after reviewing the revised demand and
supporting materials.

Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from
you.

https://www.dropbox.com/t/ZMw14HaRDOYwjiY9

*W. Bryce Koon, Esq.*

712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222

On February 17, 2025, at 10:23 a.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com to Scott Gowen at scott.gowen@louisvilleky.gov, with Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 in cc, regarding Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Jefferson County, 23-CI-005931). The subject line reflected the case, and the body began with a cordial greeting: “Good morning counsel,” followed by a brief request for any updates, and a closing with Koon’s contact information. The signature block identified The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207. The email also carried a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient, that it may contain privileged information, and instructions regarding errors and forwarding.

Earlier, on January 27, 2025, at approximately 12:17 p.m., Bryce Koon wrote to Mr. Gowen with a revised settlement demand for the above-referenced matter, noting that a revision with an attached demand had been provided. In that communication, Koon explained that all references to appendix-related issues and treatment had been removed. He acknowledged that there were still questions about the connection of those issues to the collision but stated that the removal was made to facilitate resolution and was offered as a good-faith concession. He emphasized that, even with those items removed, Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to injuries caused by the negligence of the opposing party. Consequently, he asserted that an offer in the range of $5,000 to $10,000 would be insufficient to resolve the matter. He reaffirmed a willingness to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang’s pain and suffering and asked for the recipient’s client to share their position after reviewing the revised demand and supporting materials. The message included a link to a Dropbox file: https://www.dropbox.com/t/ZMw14HaRDOYwjiY9. The email concluded with Koon’s signature and the same firm contact information as above, followed by the same attorney-client privilege disclaimer about intended recipients and protections against improper use or disclosure.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This matter is Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet in Jefferson County, case number 23-CI-005931.

The correspondence centers on a chain of emails from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, regarding the above-referenced matter. On January 27, 2025, Bryce Koon sent a message to Mr. Scott Gowen in the office of Louisville, Kentucky, with the subject that the message concerned a revised settlement demand for Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet. In that email, Koon advised that all references to appendix-related issues and treatment had been removed. He explained that, while there were still belief-based questions about the connection of those issues to the collision, the removal was intended as a good-faith effort to facilitate a resolution. He stated that Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by the defendant’s negligence, and that an offer in the range of $5,000 to $10,000 would not be sufficient to resolve the matter. Koon expressed a willingness to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang’s pain and suffering, and he requested Mr. Gowen to review the revised demand and supporting materials and to inform him of the client’s position. He provided a Dropbox link to the revised materials: https://www.dropbox.com/t/ZMw14HaRDOYwjiY9. The message concluded with Koon’s signature block, including his name, title, the firm name, the firm’s Louisville address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), and contact numbers (Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-237-3207). Like the other messages, this email carried a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain privileged information, and that if received in error the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and should not use or forward the information; the same warning and instructions about privilege applied.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up with Mr. Gowen, emailing good morning counsel and asking for any updates, expressing appreciation for any information. This message again included the standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of these communications, noting privileged or protected information and instructing anyone who received the message in error to contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the content.

Then, on March 5, 2025, Bryce Koon sent another follow-up to counsel with the same subject matter: “Good afternoon counsel, Just circling back on this one again. Thanks.” This message opened with the same courtesy and identified the sender and firm in the signature block. It again contained the firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer about attorney-client privilege and proper handling if received in error.

Across these emails, the communications demonstrate a continuing effort to move toward a settlement in Brenda Lang’s MVA case against Marcus Hamlet. The January 27, 2025 message outlined a revised settlement demand, the February 17, 2025 message sought updates, and the March 5, 2025 message issued another follow-up, all seeking resolution in light of the medical expenses Lang incurred and the related injuries. All messages were authored by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and circulated to Scott Gowen and to the Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 Filevine project email address, with the case caption and client identified as noted above.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Brenda Lang motor-vehicle accident matter (Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021), Brenda Lang is the client, and the case is Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Jefferson 23-CI-005931). Beginning with a series of email exchanges in early 2025, the parties discussed settlement prospects and the scope of medicals tied to the collision.

On January 27, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a revised settlement demand to counsel for Marcus Hamlet. In that message, Koon stated that all references to appendix-related treatment and issues had been removed. He explained that, although there were still questions about the connection of those appendix-related items to the collision, the removal was meant to demonstrate good faith to facilitate resolution. He noted that Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by the negligence of Hamlet, and that an offer in the range of $5,000 to $10,000 would be insufficient to resolve the matter. Koon expressed willingness to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang’s pain and suffering and asked the recipient to review the revised demand and supporting materials, including a Dropbox link. The message carried the standard confidentiality notice common to attorney communications and was signed with full contact details for The Whaley Law Firm. The email also referenced that the CC line included Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021’s Filevine project email address and Sarena Tuttle.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up with counsel, writing, “Good morning counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one again. Any updated appreciated,” reiterating the need for a response. This message also carried the firm’s standard confidentiality notice.

On March 5, 2025, another outside-email cautionary notice preceded Koon’s message, in which he again wrote, “Good afternoon counsel, Just circling back on this one again.” He included his contact details and the firm’s confidentiality notice.

On March 7, 2025, Scott Gowen replied. He stated that he could not get to a settlement figure of $35,000 and that any settlement would need to include indemnity for the medicals, noting that most of the medical expenses were not even attributable to the accident. He indicated that he did not have authority to settle but that he would be willing to recommend Metro Government pay $10,000 subject to the execution of a release containing broad indemnity language. He added that he would only make that recommendation if Ms. Lang would accept that amount; otherwise, he suggested proceeding to trial.

On March 25, 2025, Bryce Koon responded to Gowen, expressing that there appeared to be a misunderstanding. He stated that he had removed all references to appendix-related issues and treatment, and that the remaining medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision. He asked whether Gowen’s position was that the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision, requesting an explanation if so, and offered to resend the records if needed. The message concluded with Koon’s signature and the firm’s confidentiality provisions.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the case details, the amount of medical expenses incurred, and the extent of indemnity language necessary for any proposed settlement, all within the framework of ongoing negotiations seeking a resolution without proceeding to trial.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang. This narrative covers the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter (Jefferson County, 23-CI-005931), focusing on a series of 2025 settlement communications between counsel.

On January 27, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a revised settlement demand to Scott Gowen regarding the above-referenced case. In that message, Bryce explained that he had removed all references to appendix-related issues and treatment from the demand. He noted that while there were still questions about the connection of those appendix-related items to the collision, the parties recognized the difficulty of litigating such matters. The removal was presented as a good-faith effort to facilitate a resolution. Bryce stated that even with those items removed, Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by his client’s negligence, and that an offer in the range of $5,000 to $10,000 would not be sufficient to resolve the matter. He expressed willingness to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang’s pain and suffering, and he asked Gowen to review the revised demand and supporting materials. The email included a Dropbox link for the supporting documents and carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of such correspondence. It also contained a caution that the message originated outside Louisville Metro, advising recipients to exercise care with links and attachments, and reiterating that the information was intended only for the named recipient.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce followed up with Gowen, asking for any updates.

On March 5, 2025, Bryce sent another brief note to Gowen, again bridging the communication and reiterating the request for updates, while the message itself carried the customary external-email caution and confidentiality boilerplate.

In a reply dated March 7, 2025, Gowen acknowledged the difficulty in reaching a settlement and stated that he could not accept $35,000. He explained that any settlement would have to include an indemnity for the medicals, noting that many of the medical expenses were not attributable to the accident. Gowen indicated that he did not have authority to settle but would be willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10,000, subject to the execution of a release containing broad indemnity language. He emphasized that he would make that recommendation only if Ms. Lang would accept the amount; otherwise, he suggested proceeding to trial.

Finally, on March 25, 2025, Bryce responded to Gowen's position, signaling a continued disagreement. He stated that he believed they were not on the same page and explained that he had removed any “questionably-related” treatment concerning Ms. Lang’s appendix. Bryce asked whether Gowen contends that the September 12, 2021 ER treatment was not related to the collision and requested an explanation if that was Gowen’s position. He also offered to resend the records if needed.

Throughout these exchanges, the correspondence reflects the case details (Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet, Jefferson County, 23-CI-005931), the issue of whether certain medical treatments were connected to the collision, the removal of appendix-related treatment from the settlement demand, the claimed medical expenses (over $26,000), and the ongoing negotiation about a potential settlement versus trial. The discussions repeatedly reference the possibility of Metro Government paying a limited amount ($10,000) with broad indemnity language, contingent on Ms. Lang’s willingness to accept, and the alternative of proceeding to trial if a satisfactory resolution could not be reached.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021
Client: Brenda Lang

 Brenda Lang, the client in the matter Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Jefferson 23-CI-005931), which stems from a motor vehicle accident on September 3, 2021, has been engaging in settlement discussions with counsel for Marcus Hamlet. The communications span January through March 2025 and involve the Whaley Law Firm, led by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and counsel for the opposing side, Scott Gowen.

 In a January 27, 2025 email, Bryce Koon sent a revised settlement demand to Scott Gowen, noting that he had removed all references to appendix-related issues and treatment. He acknowledged that while there were still questions about the connection of those appendix-related items to the collision, he understood the difficulty of litigating those points. Bryce emphasized that Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to the injuries from the collision, and stated that an offer in the range of $5,000 to $10,000 would not be sufficient to resolve the matter. He attached supporting materials, including a Dropbox link, and provided his contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-237-3207. The email also included the standard privilege disclaimer and noted that the message was intended only for the named recipient.

 On February 17, 2025, Bryce followed up again, requesting any updated position after reviewing the revised demand and supporting materials. The message, like the January 27 email, carried the outside-source caution and the same contact information for The Whaley Law Firm.

 On March 5, 2025 at 12:20 PM, Bryce sent another follow-up to Scott Gowen, again seeking guidance on the case status. The message reiterated the firm’s earlier position and asked for any updates.

 On March 7, 2025 at 9:22 AM, Scott Gowen replied. He stated that he could not reach $35,000 in a settlement and that any settlement would have to include indemnity for the medicals, most of which he believed were not even attributable to the accident. He added that he did not have formal authority but would be willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10,000, subject to the execution of a release containing broad indemnity language. Gowen noted, however, that he would only make that recommendation if Ms. Lang would accept that amount; otherwise, he suggested proceeding to trial.

 That same March 7 exchange was copied to Brenda Lang’s Filevine project email address and to Sarena Tuttle at the Whaley Law Firm.

 On March 25, 2025, Bryce responded with a direct rebuke of the current stance, explaining that the parties were not on the same page. He stated that he had removed all references to the appendix-related treatment from the demand and contended that the remaining medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision. Bryce asked Scott whether the 9/12/21 emergency room treatment was considered unrelated to the collision and requested clarification. He also offered to resend any records if needed.

 Finally, on March 26, 2025 at 14:55:52 UTC, Scott Gowen closed the loop with a concise note to Bryce: he understood Bryce’s position and suggested that it might be prudent to obtain a trial date so the matter could be progressed.

 In summary, the case has involved a long-running settlement dialogue centered on medical expenses (Ms. Lang’s medical bills exceed $26,000 and potentially align with the collision’s injuries), contested connections of certain treatment and appendix-related issues, and discussions about a potential, limited indemnity-driven settlement from Metro Government (around $10,000) versus proceeding to trial, with an initial position rejecting a $35,000 figure. The communications were shared among counsel for Ms. Lang (The Whaley Law Firm), counsel for Marcus Hamlet (Scott Gowen of the Metro Government), and Ms. Lang herself via the Filevine project, with copies to Sarena Tuttle.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. Client: Brenda Lang.

Re: Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet (Jefferson 23-CI-005931).

This matter involves Brenda Lang and Marcus Hamlet in Jefferson County, case number 23-CI-005931. The following is a narrative of the email communications about the case, beginning with the latest message and then detailing the preceding exchanges.

On April 29, 2025, at 02:18:09 GMT-04:00, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Scott Gowen, with copies to Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle. The subject was the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter. In the message, Koon stated that after reviewing the file, it appeared depositions of the other passengers in Brenda Lang’s vehicle would need to be taken. He asked Gowen to provide potential dates for those individuals and included his firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email carried a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer indicating it was intended only for the named recipient and warning that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and should not use or forward the information.

Earlier communications in the thread unfolded as follows:

On March 26, 2025, at 10:56 AM (roughly), Scott Gowen replied to Bryce Koon, indicating that he understood Koon’s position and suggesting that it might make sense to set a trial date and “work this one up.”

On March 25, 2025, at 1:29 PM, Bryce Koon wrote back to Gowen. In this message, which included a caution note stating it originated from outside Louisville Metro, Koon expressed that he believed they were not on the same page. He had removed any “questionably-related” treatment concerning Ms. Lang’s appendix from the records, maintaining that the remaining medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision. He asked whether Gowen’s position was that the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision and requested an explanation if that was the case; he offered to resend the records if needed. The message was signed with Bryce Koon’s contact information.

On March 7, 2025, at 9:22 AM, Gowen replied to Bryce Koon. He stated that he could not reach $35,000 and that any settlement would need to include indemnity for the medicals, most of which he believed were not attributable to the accident. He said he had no authority but would be willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10,000, subject to a release containing broad indemnity language. He noted that he would only make that recommendation if Koon could confirm that Ms. Lang would accept that amount; otherwise, he suggested they should proceed to trial.

On March 5, 2025, at 12:20 PM, Bryce Koon sent a reply to Gowen (with Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address copied). The message, which included the standard external-email caution, began with “Good afternoon counsel” and stated that he was circling back on the matter again. It concluded with a brief sign-off containing his contact details.

On February 17, 2025, at 10:23 AM, Bryce Koon sent another message to Gowen. He wrote, “Good morning counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one. Any updated appreciated. Thank you,” and again provided his contact information.

On January 27, 2025, at 12:17 PM, Bryce Koon sent a revised settlement demand to Gowen. He explained that all references to appendix-related issues and treatment had been removed, while acknowledging there were still valid questions about the connection of those issues to the collision. He recognized the difficulty of litigating such matters but described the removal as a good-faith effort to facilitate a resolution. He noted that, even with those items removed, Ms. Lang had incurred more than $26,000 in medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by Mr. Hamlet’s negligence. He stated that an offer in the range of $5,000–$10,000 would not be sufficient to resolve the matter and expressed willingness to discuss a reasonable resolution based on documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang’s pain and suffering. He asked Gowen to let them know Metro Government’s position after reviewing the revised demand and supporting materials. The message included a Dropbox link: https://www.dropbox.com/t/ZMw14HaRDOYwjiY9. The email concluded with Bryce Koon’s signature and firm contact information, along with the standard disclaimer about attorney-client privilege and external email.

The April 29, 2025 message, referenced at the start of this narrative, was sent in the context of ongoing negotiations, with a focus on obtaining dates for depositions of other passengers and continuing to manage the litigation strategy in Brenda Lang’s favor. The thread shows a persistent effort to settle through indemnity-based releases and to address the admissibility and relevance of medical expenses tied to the collision, while exploring trial options if a settlement could not be achieved. The correspondence also reflects routine preservation of privilege notices and external-email cautions across the communications.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter (Jefferson 23-CI-005931), the case team carried on a series of settlement and discovery discussions from January through May of 2025. The proceedings centered on settlement posture, the scope of medical-related demands, and plans to depose potential witnesses and other passengers involved in the collision.

On January 27, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a revised settlement demand regarding the above-referenced matter. He noted that all references to appendix-related issues had been removed and that the remainder of the demand addressed the issues identified in the demand by treating the medicals as related to the collision. The email included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer, and the message indicated the revised demand was attached. The set of recipients included Scott Gowen from Louisville Metro Government, with copies to Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle, among others.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up, asking for any updates on the matter. No substantive changes to positions were recorded in the note, but the outreach reflected ongoing interest in progress.

By March 5, 2025, Koon again contacted Gowen, stating that he believed the two sides remained out of alignment. He explained that he had removed any “questionably-related” treatment regarding Ms. Lang’s appendix, and he asserted that the remaining medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision. He asked Gowen to indicate if the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision and offered to resend the records if needed. The message carried the external-email caution typical of communications from outside Louisville Metro.

On March 7, 2025, Gowen replied that he could not reach a $35,000 settlement and that any settlement would need to include indemnity for the medicals, most of which he contended were not attributable to the accident. He stated he did not have authority to approve a settlement, but was willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10,000, subject to the execution of a release with broad indemnity language. He emphasized that this recommendation depended on Ms. Lang’s acceptance, and otherwise suggested proceeding to trial.

The exchange continued on March 25, 2025, with Koon responding that he believed there remained a misunderstanding. He stated that he had removed the “questionably-related” appendix issues and that the remainder of the medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision. He again asked Gowen to explain whether the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision, offering to resend the records if needed.

Gowen followed up on March 26, 2025, suggesting that it might make sense to set a trial date and proceed with preparing the case toward trial rather than continuing the current settlement discussion.

On April 29, 2025, Koon wrote that, after reviewing the file, they would need to depose the other passengers in Ms. Lang’s vehicle and asked Gowen to provide potential dates for those depositions.

Finally, on May 5, 2025, Bryce Koon sent a message to Gowen stating, “We are looking to depose Wendel Smith, Marcus Cheaton, and Eric Knight.” Gowen replied later that morning, asking Koon to identify exactly who he wanted to depose and to confirm that those individuals were still employed by Metro Government. The May 5 emails continued to carry the same privilege notices and recipient lists found in the prior messages, with copies to Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle.

Across the chain, the notices reflect the ongoing effort to coordinate depositions of specific individuals (the initial three named in the May 5 email and, subsequently, the other passengers) while simultaneously negotiating a potential settlement that balances indemnity language and the attribution of medical expenses. The signature blocks consistently show The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the standard attorney contact information, and the messages include customary cautions about outside emails and privileged information.

This matter concerns Brenda Lang and her automobile-accident case against Marcus Hamlet, docketed in Jefferson County as 23-CI-005931. The following narrative summarizes the email communications among counsel and the parties from February through May 2025.

On February 17, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to counsel regarding the Lang v. Hamlet matter, stating, “Good morning counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one. Any updated appreciated.” The message included Koon’s contact details and a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and warning against disclosure if received in error.

On March 5, 2025, at 12:20 PM, Bryce Koon again wrote to Scott Gowen with Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address cc’d to Sarena Tuttle. In this outside-Louville Metro email, Koon said, “Good afternoon counsel, Just circling back on this one again,” and signed with his firm’s contact information. A CAUTION notice warned that the email originated outside Louisville Metro.

On March 7, 2025, at 9:22 AM, Gowen replied, telling Bryce that he could not reach $35,000 in settlement and that any settlement would need to include indemnity for medicals, the majority of which, he claimed, were not attributable to the accident. Gowen stated he did not have authority but was willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10,000 subject to the execution of a release with broad indemnity language, provided Lang would accept that amount; otherwise, the parties would proceed toward a trial date. This reply also included a standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On March 25, 2025, at 1:29 PM, Bryce Koon responded to Gowen, again including Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle in CC. He expressed that he believed they were not on the same page, noting that he had removed “any of the ‘questionably-related’ treatment regarding Ms. Lang’s appendix” and that the remaining medicals, as identified in the demand, were clearly related to the collision. He asked Gowen to explain if the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision and offered to resend records if needed. The message carried the standard outside-email CAUTION.

On March 26, 2025, at 10:56 AM, Gowen replied to Bryce, acknowledging Bryce’s position and suggesting that it might make sense to obtain a trial date and develop the case from there. The message concluded with Gowen’s sign-off, followed by the typical disclaimer about privileged or protected information.

On April 29, 2025, at 2:18 PM, Bryce Koon wrote to Gowen with Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle copied in. He reported that, after reviewing the file, it appeared they would need to depose the other passengers in Lang’s vehicle and asked Gowen to provide potential dates for those individuals. The message included the standard outside-email caution.

On May 5, 2025, there were two key exchanges. At 9:15 AM, Gowen replied to Bryce, apologizing for the late response and asking Bryce to identify exactly who he wanted to depose so he could check whether those individuals were still employed by Metro Government. Bryce’s response requested the depositions of Wendel Smith, Marcus Cheaton, and Eric Knight. This May 5 message from Bryce stated the deposition targets explicitly and was accompanied by his firm’s signature block, including address, phone, and fax, as well as a confidentiality disclaimer.

The May 5 exchange also reflects the ongoing discovery posture in the case, including a focus on depositions of individuals connected to Lang Lang v. Hamlet, with the primary objective of setting depositions for the potential witnesses named by Bryce Koon, Esq.

In summary, the thread from February through May 2025 shows ongoing settlement negotiations centered on indemnity for medicals and a dispute over the appropriate settlement amount, a proposal to move forward with a trial date, and a clear discovery plan that included deposing the other passengers in Brenda Lang’s vehicle and, later, specifically deposing Wendel Smith, Marcus Cheaton, and Eric Knight, as the case progressed toward trial. The correspondence repeatedly involves The Whaley Law Firm (Bryce Koon, Esq.), Scott Gowen (Metro Government counsel), Brenda Lang (the plaintiff), and Sarena Tuttle, with standard confidentiality cautions included in the outgoing emails.

episodes.natural_language:
The Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet case (Jefferson 23-CI-005931) involves client Brenda Lang, with the case file titled Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The communications in the record show a sequence of emails between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Scott Gowen of Louisville Metro, with Brenda Lang’s Filevine project email address copied on certain messages. The latest entry is a follow-up from May 21, 2025.

The first dated entry in the thread occurs on February 17, 2025, when Bryce Koon wrote to counsel, “Good morning counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one. Any updated appreciated.” The message includes the standard confidentiality disclaimer common to The Whaley Law Firm emails, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information; recipients who receive it in error should contact the firm and should not use or forward the information. A caution that the message originated outside Louisville Metro is also included in the record.

On March 5, 2025, Bryce Koon sent another message: “Good afternoon counsel, Just circling back on this one again.” This message, too, carried the outside-LouVolle Metro caution and the same confidentiality disclaimer.

On March 7, 2025, Scott Gowen replied: “Bryce, Sorry for the delay in responding. I cannot get to $35K. And any settlement would have to include indemnity for the medicals, most of which are not even attributable to the accident. I do not have any authority, but would be willing to recommend that Metro Government pay $10K subject to the execution of a release containing broad indemnity language. But I am only willing to make that recommendation if you tell me that Ms. Lang will accept that amount. Otherwise, I guess we just need to get a trial date.” This message also includes the standard confidentiality disclaimer and the outside‑the‑Metro caution.

On March 25, 2025, Bryce Koon responded: “I'm sorry Scott, but I guess I am missing something here as we are not on the same page. I have removed any of the ‘questionably-related’ treatment regarding Ms. Lang's appendix. The remainder of the medicals, as identified in the demand, are clearly related to the collision. Is it your position that the 9/12/21 ER treatment was not related to the collision? If that is the case, please explain. If you need me to resend these records, please let me know.” This message again carries the outside‑Louisville caution and the standard disclaimer.

On March 26, 2025, Gowen replied: “Bryce, I understand your position. Perhaps it makes sense to get a trial date and we can work this one up.” The message includes the usual confidentiality notice and outside‑Metro caution.

Then, on April 29, 2025, Bryce Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, After reviewing this file, it appears we will need to take the depositions of the other passengers in your client's vehicle. Are you able to provide potential dates for any of those individuals?” This email had the external-caution disclaimer and the confidentiality notice, and it CC’ed Brenda Lang MVA 09/03/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, as well as Sarena Tuttle.

Next, on May 5, 2025, there were two messages. The first, at about 9:15 AM, was from Scott Gowen: “Bryce, Sorry for the late response. Please identify exactly who you want to take and I will check to see if they are still employed by Metro Government.” The message again contained the customary confidentiality disclaimer and the outside‑Louisville caution. A few minutes later, Bryce Koon replied: “Good morning counsel, We are looking to depose Wendel Smith, Marcus Cheaton, and Eric Knight.” This reply also included the same disclaimers and caution.

Finally, on May 21, 2025, Bryce Koon sent another follow-up to counsel: “Good morning counsel, Just wanted to follow up on this. Thanks,” signed with his name and title from The Whaley Law Firm, The message again carried the confidentiality disclaimer and the standard outside‑Louisville Metro caution.

Across these exchanges, the record reflects a focus on scheduling depositions (specifically of Wendel Smith, Marcus Cheaton, Eric Knight, and the other passengers in Brenda Lang’s vehicle) and ongoing negotiations regarding settlement amounts and indemnity for medicals, as well as consideration of trial timing. The thread includes multiple CCs to Brenda Lang’s Filevine address and notes the involvement of Sarena Tuttle in some communications. Each email contains a confidential attorney‑client disclaimer and a caution about outside communication.

In the Brenda Lang v. Marcus Hamlet matter (Jefferson 23-CI-005931), Brenda Lang is the client in a motor vehicle accident case designated as Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021. The following narrative summarizes the email correspondence between The Whaley Law Firm and Scott Gowen, counsel for Louisville Metro Government, from early 2025 through June 30, 2025, including the ongoing deposition and settlement discussions.

On March 7, 2025, Scott Gowen replied to Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm. Gowen stated that he could not reach a settlement of $35,000 and that any settlement would have to include indemnity for the medicals, most of which he argued were not attributable to the accident. He indicated he had no authority to authorize a higher amount but suggested Metro Government might pay $10,000 subject to a release containing broad indemnity language, provided Brenda Lang would accept that amount; otherwise, he suggested we proceed toward a trial date.

A week later, on March 25, 2025, Bryce Koon responded. He explained that, after reviewing the file, it appeared the depositions of the other passengers in Brenda Lang’s vehicle would be required. He asked Scott Gowen to provide potential dates for those individuals. He also noted that he had previously removed “any of the ‘questionably-related’ treatment” regarding Lang’s appendix, and that the remaining medicals identified in the demand were clearly related to the collision.
